headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2010 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call.  For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2010 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call.  For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to CSC's Earnings Call for the Third Quarter of Our Fiscal Year 2010. We hope you had the chance to review our financial results, which were issued earlier this morning. With me today are Mike Laphe
componenttext: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to CSC's Earnings Call for the Third Quarter of Our Fiscal Year 2010. We hope you had the chance to review our financial results, which were issued earlier this morning. With me today are Mike Laphen, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Mancuso, our Chief Financial Officer.  As usual, this call is being webcast at csc.com, and we've also posted slides to our website to accompany this discussion. If you can turn to Slide 2, there's the usual reminder that statements made during this call that are not historical facts may be considered forward-looking statements under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties is contained in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies of these filings are available from the SEC, from our website and from our Investor Relations Department. Slide 3 acknowledges that CSC's presentation includes certain non-GAAP financial measures. In accordance with SEC rules, a reconciliation of these metrics to GAAP metrics is included in the Tables of the earnings release and in the Appendix to our slides. Both documents are available for your review at the Investor Relations section of the CSC website. Finally, I'd like to remind our listeners that CSC assumes no obligation to update the information presented on this conference call, except of course as required by law.  So if you'll kindly move to Slide #4, I'm pleased to turn the call over to Mike Laphen.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bryan, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results built upon the successful performance we delivered in the first half of the fiscal year. Despite a market that is still on recovery, we achieved both solid business and financial perf
componenttext: Thank you, Bryan, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results built upon the successful performance we delivered in the first half of the fiscal year. Despite a market that is still on recovery, we achieved both solid business and financial performance in the third quarter. We're particularly pleased with the continuing ramp up in new business bookings, which we believe affirms the marketability and innovativeness of our expanding offerings and solution sets. These offerings, coupled with our focus on selected high-growth sectors, have increased our opportunity pipeline and positioned us for the accomplishment of our long-term financial objective of growth with improved profitability.Slide 5 summarizes the major highlights of the third quarter's performance. We achieved significant new business bookings, delivered solid EPS growth, continued to expand our operating margins, held year-over-year revenue stable, delivered cash performance ahead of our plan, and most importantly, we continue to deliver real results and value to our growing list of clients.Continually improving profitability has been a consistent objective of this management team. All three lines of business expanded operating margins sequentially, yielding an improvement of 110 basis points. On a year-over-year basis, operating margin improved 15 basis points. This continued expansion derives from improved operational performance, recurring benefits from our cost structure improvement programs and ongoing proactive management of expenses.We anticipate that the net effect of these efforts will be margin improvement at the upper end of our target range of 25 to 50 basis points for the full fiscal year. Revenue of $4 billion, net of a non-core disposition, was in line with our expectation and on track with our full year guidance of $16 billion to $16.5 billion. We anticipate a ramping up of revenues in our fourth quarter, with about half of the growth coming from seasonal productivity factors and the rest coming from a combination of existing contract growth and new business wins.  Mike Mancuso will have more in-depth review of our third quarter results in his commentary.Turning to Slide 6, in New Business Bookings, as I said earlier, new business bookings continued at a robust pace, reflecting continuing demand for CSC's innovative solutions and mission-critical delivery. For the third quarter, we delivered bookings of $6.8 billion. This result is up $4.1 billion over last year's third quarter performance and also up $2.2 billion sequentially.Year-to-date, through the third quarter, new business bookings totaled $14.9 billion, which puts us in an excellent position to meet or exceed our bookings guidance of $17 billion to $18 billion for the full year. In aggregate, new business awards give us a positive book-to-revenue ratio of 1.7 for the third quarter and 1.3 year-to-date.Importantly, we're also growing our client base. Through the third quarter, we have signed over 96 new client accounts across our commercial businesses. Our strong book-to-revenue ratios and our expanding set of clients will contribute to the fiscal year revenue growth profile.Within our lines of business, our Managed Services Sector posted strong third quarter bookings of $5.2 billion, including new client wins, as well as the extension and expansion of our work with Raytheon and Zurich Financial Services. Through the end of the third quarter, MSS bookings totaled $6.6 billion. This is a 57% increase over last year's sum of $4.2 billion.NPS [North American Public Sector] bookings of $800 million were modest for the quarter, reflecting the delay of approximately $2.7 billion of awards expected to occur within our third quarter. These delays, plus the additional delays from the protest of announced awards, have elongated the Federal procurement process for the industry as a whole. For CSC, these delays impacted both our bookings and our revenue for the quarter. However, for year-to-date through the end of the third quarter, NPS bookings of $5.7 billion in new business and achieved a constructive book-to-revenue ratio of 1.2.Moving to Slide 7, I'd like to share our perspective on the market and comment on our business outlook. Across our global commercial businesses, we continue to see encouraging signs of market recovery. More specifically, the pipeline of our Managed Services business remains strong, with about $14 billion in opportunities scheduled to be decided by the end of our fiscal year '11. For the fourth quarter, we expect MSS to deliver continued new business success and positive sequential and year-over-year revenue growth.The Outsourcing market, including application, appears stronger than it has been for the last two years. And we anticipate that clients' escalating concerns with vendor lock-in and their growing interest in Trusted Cloud, virtualization, hosting and system management solutions and services will continue to fuel our bookings. The growing concern and visibility regarding cyber-security issues is also a significant opportunity for us. We are leveraging our considerable government expertise to assist commercial clients in the protection of their computing environments, networks, data and applications.Our Business Solutions and Services line of business has, for the most part, remain stable, with increasing signs of recovery in the transformation and application space. Overall, utilization has been stable for three quarters, with an expected uptick in Q4. Pipeline activity is headed in a positive direction, although geographic markets are at different stages of recovery. Within EMEA, we're seeing a steady market in France and an improving markets in the United Kingdom and the Nordics. Public sector demand is particularly strong in the U.K. and France. Australia's economy appears to be back to its trend growth, and Asia is leading the economic recovery. Economics uncertainties continue to impact the German and some U.S. markets.In Latin America, the integration of our recent acquisition in Brazil has been well received by customers in that market. And we recently closed two significant ERP integration contracts with Brazilian utilities. We also signed several ERP integration engagements in France, with clients in manufacturing, pharmaceutical and construction industries. We view these transformational initiatives as a constructive sign of market recovery.For the fourth quarter, we anticipate that BSS revenues will show a positive growth sequentially and year-over-year. The degree of growth will be influenced by client's confidence as they begin to eschew their budgets within their new calendar years. We continue to believe the drivers for their budget initiatives will remain cost control and regulatory compliance, along with the gradual return to those transformational initiatives that improve compare to the market position and grow their businesses.Our MPS [Managed Print Services] new business pipeline remains strong, with some $21 billion awards currently scheduled to be announced by the end of our fiscal year '11. Our pipeline includes 33 qualified opportunities, over $100 million in value and provides us with a platform for revenue growth. Our initial evaluation of the newly-released Obama budget renews our confidence that the breadth of our market footprint and our selected strategic focus areas should enable us to deliver continued growth, as the administration's priorities shift spending profiles.The administration has described spending in terms of two categories: Security and non-security spending. Security spending will increase about 5% to $719 billion, while non-security spending will decrease by about $5 billion or 1% to $441 billion. Our strong business base across all areas related to security will benefit, as Defense, Intelligence and Homeland Security budgets remain intact or are increased. In the non-security area, most agencies' budgets are expected to be frozen. Here, we see opportunities for growth by targeting initiatives in those specific areas where funding is provided. To illustrate, the new NASA budget realigns the manned space flight budget elements and direct spending towards research and development, rather than building vehicles. This is a positive for service providers rather than for hardware platform providers. Additionally, the Science budget, particularly for earth sciences is increased. And we view climate change and the supporting science as a future growth area.Lastly, major IT consolidation programs do not seem to be affected in any major way. Other civil areas offering growth potential for CSC include a whole range of health initiatives, among others.The President's budget specifically included $79.4 billion for IT. Key projects in this portion of the budget include initiatives in cloud computing, cyber security, procurement transparency, performance management and data center consolidation. Our high-growth initiatives are well aligned with these specific areas of spending increases. Within the new budget, there are proposed terminations, savings and reductions affecting some 126 programs. These targeted areas of spending decline move [ph] to have little to no impact on our business.Lastly, the administration's new budget proposal also calls for a significant increase in the size of the acquisition workforce, which will hopefully address the issues of procurement delays and protest I mentioned earlier.Overall, we expect to see continued opportunity and success in the U.S. Federal market and an expanding presence in state and local markets. Led by our high-growth initiatives, we believe that the U.S. public sector will continue to be a healthy productive market for CSC. To that end, we expect MPS to deliver mid-single digit growth this fiscal year and mid- to upper-single digit growth next fiscal year.A few words on the NHS [National Health Service)] program, within our NHS program, we continue to deliver and expand our production operations. In the third quarter, three additional trusts went live on Lorenzo Release 1, bringing the total number of Lorenzo production sites to seven, with several more in flight. For our healthcare solution for general practitioners, we now have over 1,100 systems in production operations supporting over 458,000 active users who provide care for over 15 million English citizens. As we discussed on our last call, we successfully went live with the Lorenzo Care Management at Bury. Our next significant NHS event is the planned appointment of Lorenzo Care Management at Morecambe Bay. This is scheduled to occur towards the end of our fourth quarter, and we are currently on track. Lastly, we're in discussion with NHS authority regarding the government's announced intention to reduce the spending profile of their overall program. We expect to achieve an outcome regarding CSC's portion of the program that is constructive for all parties by the end of the fourth quarter.Looking forward, our third quarter results enable us to reaffirm our full year guidance for all key financial metrics and to guide to the upper end of our EPS range.  At this point, I'd like to turn the call over to Mike Mancuso for further detail on this quarter's financials and for our outlook for the fourth quarter and our full year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Before I get into the numbers, as most of you are aware, the timing of this year's press release and analyst call marks a significant departure from CSC's past practice. Historically, we have released
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Before I get into the numbers, as most of you are aware, the timing of this year's press release and analyst call marks a significant departure from CSC's past practice. Historically, we have released our financial results at the end of the day after the market closed, and then almost immediately thereafter, initiating the call. That of course did not allow much time for you to parse the numbers and formulate your questions. Hopefully, this current routine will help facilitate more targeted discussions. In any event, we certainly invite your feedback on the timing of this call. Now I'll get to the numbers. First of all, as Mike Laphen does, I feel very good about the quarter. We are on track to meet or beat all of the financial targets we set for ourselves this year. And as you'll see, we are further strengthening the balance sheet and are very well positioned for next year. If you'll turn to Chart 9, Chart 9 delineates what we see as the more significant accomplishments in the quarter. Mike has already addressed the new business awards, so I won't dwell further on that, except to suggest that this bodes well for our future revenue growth.As you can see, EPS of $1.36. That's about $0.11 higher than the top end of our guidance. I'll have more to say about this. Our tax rate for the quarter has dropped by roughly eight percentage points from our previous estimate. And our annual rate will drop from our previously-discussed 28% to 24%. Sequential revenue stability, sequentially for the first three quarters of this year, our revenue has been at constant at roughly $4 billion per quarter. And our third quarter revenue was comparable to last year. We view this stable revenue as a positive in a difficult economic times. And as you'll see later, we do anticipate meaningful revenue growth in our fourth quarter.  Operating income growth and margin rate improvement, operating income is up both sequentially and year-over-year and the same is true of our margin rates. And we remain on track to achieve the high end of our full year guidance.Now if you'll turn to Chart 10, Revenue by Line of Business (sic) [Revenue by Lines of Business], you can see the third quarter sector revenue this year is comparable to last year. In NPS, the delayed new program starts and protest had slowed growth. MSS, slightly higher than last year, has been able to offset the impact of contract completions and scope reductions by troubled clients. And BSS, most impacted by the economic downturn, is holding its own, and in fact, has been able to offset about a $40 million reduction in revenue due to having sold our value-added reseller business in Hong Kong at the end of last year.Chart 11 shows income by line of business. MSS and BSS are comparable to last year, with the uptick provided by NPS. Roughly, one full percentage point of NPS' margin or about $14 million is attributable to a net one-time pickup from a contract modification. And anticipating questions along these lines, I can tell you that we do expect further margin rate expansion in MSS and BSS in the fourth quarter, coupled with revenue growth. And as I said earlier, we also expect to meet our 25 to 50 basis point margin improvement goal for this fiscal year, more likely closer to a 50-basis point gain. Chart 12, Selected Financial Information, gives you the snapshot high-level P&L. Increased operating income and $11 million favorable swing in other income and the tax rate change drive the EPS growth.Chart 13, the Selected Balance Sheet Items, the short message on this chart is that we have more cash, improved the receivables, less debt and our debt-to-capital ratios have improved.Chart 14, which displays our days receivable outstanding (sic) [days sales outstanding] or DSOs, reflects the continuing improvement in receivables. In absolutes, we are five days better than last year. On average, six days better; and thus, in position to meet our annual goal of at least a five-day reductionChart 15, Selected Cash Flow Items, what this Chart doesn't show is where we are relative to our internal plan. We are almost $200 million favorable to our internal plan and expect to meet our full year goal of free cash flow at or above 90% of net income. As you can see, when compared to last year, net earnings are higher, depreciation is lower, capital expenditures are also lower. The non-receivables portion of working capital has increased, and that's predominantly work-in-process, lower advances and accrued expenses.  And to reiterate, we fully expect to meet our annual cash flow guidance of free cash flow in excess of 90% of net income. Now that brings us to Chart 16 and a discussion of EPS, including a forecast for the fourth quarter. If you will focus on quarter 3, you can see the $1.36 result. And as indicated below the bar, our guidance was between $1.20 and $1.25. So we exceeded the high end of our guidance by $0.11.Looking ahead to quarter 4, we are forecasting $1.37, which is within our guidance. Now included in the $1.37 estimate are two unrelated discretionary actions that, when combined, lower EPS by approximately $0.33. You can see on the bar, and as I understand it may be difficult to see from the webcast charts, the very top end of that fourth quarter bar, would've been higher than $1.37 by about $0.33 if we did not intend to execute these discretionary items.The two items I referred to as discretionary are a discretionary contribution of $25 million to our 401(k) plan and the early retirement of $500 million of 7 3/8% coupon term notes that are otherwise due in June of 2011. We have considered the 401(k) contribution throughout this year, and it was embodied in the contribution guidance we discussed on this call in May of last year, when we announced the freeze of our U.S. defined benefit plan.The debt retirement increases interest expense in the fourth quarter by about $45 million and lowers FY '11's interest expense by a comparable amount. Whether or not we replace that debt with additional borrowings next year is yet to be determined, as we are working our way through our FY '11 detailed financial plans. So if you'll now turn to Chart 17, it reflects a full year EPS of $4.98, which is at the high end of our guidance.Chart 18 is the detailed P&L for the year, with the year-to-date actual on the left through the third quarter and the details of our fourth quarter estimate. For the fourth quarter estimate, operating income and interest expense are highlighted. Revenue for the quarter is estimated at $4.4 billion, roughly a 10% sequential increase and 7% above fourth quarter of last year.OI income of $445 million is net of the $25 million discretionary 401(k) contribution. Interest expense of $91 million includes the $45 million additional debt retirement-related interest expense.  The far right-hand column details our full year. Revenue, margin rate and EPS are all well within the guidance parameters we have shared with you throughout the year. And as far as next year is concerned, we think we are postured for meaningful revenue growth as the economic recovery continues. We do not intend on this call to offer any specific guidance or commentary regarding next year. That will come in our May call, when we wrap up this year and offer guidance on next year.Internally, we are in the early stages of our FY '11 detailed budget preparation, and that exercise will be completed in late March. However, there is one important aspect affecting next year that you should incorporate into your thinking. This year, our effective tax rate is roughly 24%. Next year's rate will likely be in the low-30s. 32% is probably a good number for now. Accelerating this term debt pay off will reduce interest expense next year, assuming for the moment no additional borrowings, somewhat offsetting the effect of the tax rate increase. So please keep that in mind as you think about next year.So on Chart 19, going into the fourth quarter, we feel good about this year and are well positioned going into next year. And to reiterate, we do expect to meet all the FY '10 financial guidance we set out earlier this year with more value to come.  So with that said, I'll turn it back to Bryan to begin the questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And we'll take our first session today from Darrin Peller with Barclays Capital.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to touch first on the margin improvement. I think it was pretty impressive and consistent throughout the year. And just maybe, Mike, you can give a little more color as to the detail around the change sequentially and year-over-year and really gi
componenttext: I'd like to touch first on the margin improvement. I think it was pretty impressive and consistent throughout the year. And just maybe, Mike, you can give a little more color as to the detail around the change sequentially and year-over-year and really give us a sense of what is left for next year?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we do not intend to rest on our laurels. I think we outlined for the folks that had attended our investor conference last November that we fully expect it to continue the march toward margin improvement in the coming years, and that we wo
componenttext: Well, certainly, we do not intend to rest on our laurels. I think we outlined for the folks that had attended our investor conference last November that we fully expect it to continue the march toward margin improvement in the coming years, and that we would target something to the tune of about another  25- or 50-basis point improvement going forward. It's obviously -- I don't think it's any one element, but it's every element of our performance from the large-scale things that we can control to improved execution, better managed travel expense, space reductions across the world, as we continue our analysis of our space need, et cetera, et cetera. It's really a number of things across all the spectrum, better activities around capitalization. We'll keep an eye on the interest rates next year. So our efforts are concentrated on that, which is in the operating income side of things and those items between operating income and net income that we can affect by prudent action. So I hope that's -- it's kind of a general answer, but it's kind of where we are.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, Mike, that I think also you need to look in the context of the business mix, particularly with the new business levels that we're winning, with infusing that revenue stream and that will, come at a better margin and also we'll re
componenttext: I would just add to that, Mike, that I think also you need to look in the context of the business mix, particularly with the new business levels that we're winning, with infusing that revenue stream and that will, come at a better margin and also we'll reflect and enhance our ability to increase our offshore mix of employees, which today is around 32%, 33% and we've set ourselves a target of 50% over the three-year period. So good opportunity and improved margins through the mix of business as well.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

componenttext: Another question on the next quarter, your discretionary items, you alluded to around the 401-K plans and the debt extinguishment. Your guidance suggest that you'll have over $800 million, at least $800 million of free cash next quarter alone, and that, I guess, taken to account those two items as well?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the debt -- the discretionary, yes. The debt repayment would be outside free cash flow and investing activities. So the 800-plus million would be mildly pro-rata data by the $25 million portfo and K [401(k)] contribution. Whether debt repayment in i
componenttext: Well, the debt -- the discretionary, yes. The debt repayment would be outside free cash flow and investing activities. So the 800-plus million would be mildly pro-rata data by the $25 million portfo and K [401(k)] contribution. Whether debt repayment in investing activities and not necessarily part of the free cash flow calculation.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to address the bookings pipeline a little bit. Obviously, the third quarter was solid, but what are the next few quarters looking like? Do you think you can get into the $4 billion to $5 billion range near term, and will the mix change at all bet
componenttext: I wanted to address the bookings pipeline a little bit. Obviously, the third quarter was solid, but what are the next few quarters looking like? Do you think you can get into the $4 billion to $5 billion range near term, and will the mix change at all between the different business segments?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, we're targeting $17 million to $18 million for the full year. So that requires another good quarter in the fourth quarter, which we anticipate and we believe we have opportunity to exceed that $17 million to $18 billion level. So looking
componenttext: Well, as I said, we're targeting $17 million to $18 million for the full year. So that requires another good quarter in the fourth quarter, which we anticipate and we believe we have opportunity to exceed that $17 million to $18 billion level. So looking to next quarter, we think it should be a pretty good quarter and a very good year. Going beyond that, the pipelines are robust. The pipelines are robust in the outsourcing arena, particularly. They're also robust in our public sector business. So the outsourcing as you know, can be bumpy by quarter. So I'm reluctant to say quarter by quarter it's going to be the $4 billion to $5 billion, because you do get lump sum with some of the outsourcing. But from what we see near term, it looks good for us. It's very good and on a more extended range, we like what we see the pipeline.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that on the discretionary side, especially in BSS, we are seeing a pick up there in small projects. It's not pre-crisis levels but we are definitely seeing a pickup on the discretionary side. Can you talk about BSS as well and then maybe, M
componenttext: Just to add to that on the discretionary side, especially in BSS, we are seeing a pick up there in small projects. It's not pre-crisis levels but we are definitely seeing a pickup on the discretionary side. Can you talk about BSS as well and then maybe, Mike Mancuso, you can wrap this part of the conversation up with, can you still increased margins by 25 to 50 basis points if more of your bookings maybe coming from MPS than OS, which I think are lower margin than in some other areas?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to talk to the BSS, the activity is picking up. We're projecting high utilization in the fourth quarter. I think I alluded to that in my commentary. We do see increased interest in the transformational opportunities. I think we're going to continue t
componenttext: Just to talk to the BSS, the activity is picking up. We're projecting high utilization in the fourth quarter. I think I alluded to that in my commentary. We do see increased interest in the transformational opportunities. I think we're going to continue to see how this plays out. So we're cautiously optimistic, I would say, in the BSS space. As I said earlier, it's been stable for three quarters. We expect the uptick in the fourth quarter and hopefully that trend or slope will continue.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. Certainly BSS is -- we're guardedly optimistic. Obviously, the pickup would come. Right now, there's significant amount of competitive pressure within BSS et cetera. But we think that, that would increase business and what
componenttext: And Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. Certainly BSS is -- we're guardedly optimistic. Obviously, the pickup would come. Right now, there's significant amount of competitive pressure within BSS et cetera. But we think that, that would increase business and what we have to offer that we can win new business in BSS at very favorable margin rates and continue our march towards a low single digit margin rate certainly in BSS in the coming quarters.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The offshore players are making some pretty solid headway into the infrastructure business with their rim offerings. Covansys spoke about it yesterday, other players have spoken about it on the earning seasons calls. How does CSE counter the push from the
componenttext: The offshore players are making some pretty solid headway into the infrastructure business with their rim offerings. Covansys spoke about it yesterday, other players have spoken about it on the earning seasons calls. How does CSE counter the push from the India-based firms into RIM and what impact are you seeing in pricing so far?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll, RIM is nothing you for us. We've been doing Remote Infrastructure Management for long time. We've been doing it from a global perspective. So my perspective position is that we're significantly ahead of the Indian peer placing. And frankly, they do
componenttext: We'll, RIM is nothing you for us. We've been doing Remote Infrastructure Management for long time. We've been doing it from a global perspective. So my perspective position is that we're significantly ahead of the Indian peer placing. And frankly, they do have a long way to go to be able to be a real global provider of RIM. So they're there, I'm sure they'll be aggressive competitors but clearly, with the bookings that we're showing right now, we're not being negatively impacted by whatever actions they're doing out there.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, another way to look at it, I think NPS is expected to grow mid to high single-digits in the fourth quarter. In order to get to the $4.4 billion, it looks like both managed services and business solutions services need to grow high single-digits o
componenttext: I guess, another way to look at it, I think NPS is expected to grow mid to high single-digits in the fourth quarter. In order to get to the $4.4 billion, it looks like both managed services and business solutions services need to grow high single-digits or does one grow faster than the other when we look at the fourth quarter?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me first of all remind you that there are some NHS milestones in the fourth quarter that will bring with it revenue recognition. So that has some influence, not total by any stretch influence on the BSS number. As Mike had indicated, those miles
componenttext: Well, let me first of all remind you that there are some NHS milestones in the fourth quarter that will bring with it revenue recognition. So that has some influence, not total by any stretch influence on the BSS number. As Mike had indicated, those milestones and those performances are on track. So we fully expect to achieve that. So the stretch on the other parts of the business, when you start up activities in MSS, including the new awards that we have talked about, the effort beginning of those new awards, et cetera. To give you some comfort, we have detailed insight into the projections for the quarter. We already have January under our belt, so to speak. So we're confident that fourth quarter is achievable for the quarter.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And should we expect MSS or BSS to grow faster than the other or equal or just trying to figure out the modeling aspect here?
componenttext: And should we expect MSS or BSS to grow faster than the other or equal or just trying to figure out the modeling aspect here?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think probably with the NHS influence, BSS should grow a little bit more in the quarter and NPS will have a significant growth in the fourth quarter. Probably the one that will grow the least in the quarter percentage-wide would be MSS. Look at NPS
componenttext: Well I think probably with the NHS influence, BSS should grow a little bit more in the quarter and NPS will have a significant growth in the fourth quarter. Probably the one that will grow the least in the quarter percentage-wide would be MSS. Look at NPS and BSS as the bigger contributors to revenue growth in the fourth quarter.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Mike, you talked about the U.K. government, having discussions with them about potential reduction in NHS spend. What are the potential outcomes? We've heard a lot press there, but you said you'd discuss it over the quarter. But where is this goi
componenttext: And then Mike, you talked about the U.K. government, having discussions with them about potential reduction in NHS spend. What are the potential outcomes? We've heard a lot press there, but you said you'd discuss it over the quarter. But where is this going to lead or any hints that would be helpful.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just say that the government has publicly said that they would like to reduce the program, the total program, not just our piece, but all the vendors' piece as well is the internal spend by about 600 million pounds over the life of the program. And
componenttext: Let me just say that the government has publicly said that they would like to reduce the program, the total program, not just our piece, but all the vendors' piece as well is the internal spend by about 600 million pounds over the life of the program. And so we're working with them on a portion of that with us. I think it's a very constructive engagement. And at the end of the day, I think we're going to work something out that satisfies their needs as well as ours. And that's the way went into this. So we recognize that we need some fiscal savings and if they realize that we've made investments and commitments in line with the start of this contract. So again, as I said during the comments, I think it's going to be a constructive outcome, and I don't think you should -- if you take it in the context of the whole scale of this contract and the length of this contract, I guess the only thing I could suggest to you is I would not overreact as to any expectations here. And you've got a point in the context that there's an election coming up over there, there's a lot of political rhetoric. If you recall back to our election and the rhetoric that went on and all the promises that were made and what level there coming to be true at this point in time, I think you just got to keep all that in perspective when you talk about NHS. So we're feeling confident about where we are, we're encouraged that we're on track with another critical milestone and I think we have an extremely good working relationship with the client.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And Bryan, this is Mike Mancuso again. Let me come back to your question on the growth in the quarter and constant currency. With the good help of the folks in the room, we have to pull out the number. It's about 1% in the fourth quarter growth. Just some
componenttext: And Bryan, this is Mike Mancuso again. Let me come back to your question on the growth in the quarter and constant currency. With the good help of the folks in the room, we have to pull out the number. It's about 1% in the fourth quarter growth. Just something about 1% in constant currency growth in the quarter. And just to add to that, to kind of take the whole year in perspective, our best guess for the full year is that our revenue will have declined through the full year in constant currency, something less than 3%. And in this environment, we feel very, very good about that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, on the tax rate, it's been below 30% all year and it seems like you continue to surprise on the tax rate. What would be the reasons why tax rate would go up to the low-30s since it's been in the kind of the mid to low-20s all year?
componenttext: Mike, on the tax rate, it's been below 30% all year and it seems like you continue to surprise on the tax rate. What would be the reasons why tax rate would go up to the low-30s since it's been in the kind of the mid to low-20s all year?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: In this year, we have the benefit of the number of nonrecurring items, one of which is some net operating losses out of our international area of, particularly in Germany that don't repeat next year. So that's probably, if there's one single thing across
componenttext: In this year, we have the benefit of the number of nonrecurring items, one of which is some net operating losses out of our international area of, particularly in Germany that don't repeat next year. So that's probably, if there's one single thing across many individual initiatives, the impact of those German NOLs won't repeat next year. But when you think about the aggressiveness of the states and tax rates going forward and so on and so forth, 32% is not too shabby.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: George Price with Stifel, Nicolaus has our next question.
componenttext: George Price with Stifel, Nicolaus has our next question.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up if I could to a couple of things. First, on a cash flow. I guess cash flow in the quarter, worse than expected and I apologize if you went over this at some point. But Mike, what happened, was it timing issues? Was it NHS? Can y
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up if I could to a couple of things. First, on a cash flow. I guess cash flow in the quarter, worse than expected and I apologize if you went over this at some point. But Mike, what happened, was it timing issues? Was it NHS? Can you get a little bit more specific on what usually's a more stronger quarter seasonally for cash flow?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, worse than expected, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, it wasn't worse than what we expected. It's actually better by $200 million to our internal plan. Year-over-year, comparisons of cash flow are difficult obviously, particularly when you have
componenttext: Well, worse than expected, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, it wasn't worse than what we expected. It's actually better by $200 million to our internal plan. Year-over-year, comparisons of cash flow are difficult obviously, particularly when you have significant swings and milestones that may or may not occur in a given quarter. So if we surprise in the negative, we're sorry about that, but we're very comfortable around the cash in the quarter and encourage, if I might add, the word in terms of our ability to meet our full-year guidance. So there was nothing aberrational there that we hadn't anticipated.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the improvement that you expect and that's implied in the guidance next quarter, obviously, if you look back, seasonality is a big factor in the fiscal fourth quarter. I guess, other drivers would be expected milestone payments related to NHS
componenttext: In terms of the improvement that you expect and that's implied in the guidance next quarter, obviously, if you look back, seasonality is a big factor in the fiscal fourth quarter. I guess, other drivers would be expected milestone payments related to NHS with Morecambe Bay? Any other milestones? Any other timing issues that you can elaborate on?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Probably the single event, if you can see that in the quarter, that would be a contributor, of course will be the NHS milestones and advances that will come with that execution. But that's a portion of it, but certainly not the entire portion. As a matter
componenttext: Probably the single event, if you can see that in the quarter, that would be a contributor, of course will be the NHS milestones and advances that will come with that execution. But that's a portion of it, but certainly not the entire portion. As a matter of fact, it's well [ph] less than 50% of the cash in the fourth quarter. It's just deliveries and some seasonality. But other than NHS milestones, nothing aberrational in the quarter.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of demand, I wanted to follow-up on one thing that you said around BSS, especially around larger transformational opportunities. You said that it's been kind of stable and you're seeing some more activity and I guess, some improving interest. But
componenttext: In terms of demand, I wanted to follow-up on one thing that you said around BSS, especially around larger transformational opportunities. You said that it's been kind of stable and you're seeing some more activity and I guess, some improving interest. But it sounds to me that in terms of the actual getting new deals, spending started in new deals done. It sounds like maybe the pickup has been progressing maybe a little bit slower than you thought coming into this year. Is that fair?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't characterize it that way. To be honest, in that particular area, we weren't all that optimistic on when the activity would pick up. So I guess from our perspective, we're starting to get some of the bookings and I referred to some of them.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't characterize it that way. To be honest, in that particular area, we weren't all that optimistic on when the activity would pick up. So I guess from our perspective, we're starting to get some of the bookings and I referred to some of them. And some of them global, for instance, the ones I talked about in France and Brazil and elsewhere in different markets. So I think it really varies by geographical markets, I would say that first and foremost. But I would say that it's a bit up more than we expected, but I don't want to give the impression that I think it's robust, by any means. I think we still have a good way to go. It's a positive slope but it's not indicating that things are back to normal, if you will.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The two discretionary items, were they originally factored in guidance or have they been in guidance recently or are you basically just using the opportunity of the lower tax rate to kind of knock these out?
componenttext: The two discretionary items, were they originally factored in guidance or have they been in guidance recently or are you basically just using the opportunity of the lower tax rate to kind of knock these out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The discretionary 401(k) contribution, as I said, was embodied in our guidance throughout the year. The tax rate improvement gave us some latitude in terms of being able to address the debt repayment opportunity, but also the credit markets have also stim
componenttext: The discretionary 401(k) contribution, as I said, was embodied in our guidance throughout the year. The tax rate improvement gave us some latitude in terms of being able to address the debt repayment opportunity, but also the credit markets have also stimulated our interest in paying down at 7% debt, should we need to borrow next year for whatever needs we could borrow at a much cheaper rate than what we're currently paying on that debt. And there is a minor improvement arbitrage-wise with the early payment. Not outstanding by any stretch, but also it presents an opportunity.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to Karl Keirstead with Kaufman Brothers.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now go to Karl Keirstead with Kaufman Brothers.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, this one is about the March quarter operating margin improvement. CSC's had up year-over-year adjusted operating margins, seems almost every quarter for the last couple of years. But your guidance for 10.1% operating margins and then even if we add
componenttext: Mike, this one is about the March quarter operating margin improvement. CSC's had up year-over-year adjusted operating margins, seems almost every quarter for the last couple of years. But your guidance for 10.1% operating margins and then even if we add back the $25 million of 401(k) contribution, it feels like it's going to be down from the $10.9 million from last year. I want to get a sense for whether there's anything in the March quarter beyond that 410(k) contribution that might sort of break the streak of up year-over-year margins?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The quick answer, Carl, is no, I can't think of anything other than the 410(k) contribution in the quarter. Last year, just to be specific, I think the margin rate was 10.8 fixed, and this year, excluding the discretionary $25 million, the number would be
componenttext: The quick answer, Carl, is no, I can't think of anything other than the 410(k) contribution in the quarter. Last year, just to be specific, I think the margin rate was 10.8 fixed, and this year, excluding the discretionary $25 million, the number would be 10.68. So it's slightly down, if you will. But again, it's a mixed issue. If it's anything, there's nothing unique in there. So nothing that we can think of at this point that is unusual.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi has our next question.
componenttext: Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi has our next question.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the growth question, and if you could break out your bookings to date by renewals versus new logos? And then talk about the dates, as new logos potentially become a bigger part of future bookings, do you expect that to have -- or wh
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the growth question, and if you could break out your bookings to date by renewals versus new logos? And then talk about the dates, as new logos potentially become a bigger part of future bookings, do you expect that to have -- or what kind of an impact do you expect that to have on both CapEx, working capital margins?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The way we look at it is new logos and new specific expanded work for an existing logo. And of the bookings to date, which is $14.9 billion, about 75% of that would go into our new category and about 25% would be included in our recompete or follow-on bus
componenttext: The way we look at it is new logos and new specific expanded work for an existing logo. And of the bookings to date, which is $14.9 billion, about 75% of that would go into our new category and about 25% would be included in our recompete or follow-on business, if you will.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Ashwin, it's pretty difficult at this point to give you any detail around how those bookings break down and how they might affect the CapEx or working capital margin. Certainly, the outsourcing contracts would carry more of a working capital requirement t
componenttext: Ashwin, it's pretty difficult at this point to give you any detail around how those bookings break down and how they might affect the CapEx or working capital margin. Certainly, the outsourcing contracts would carry more of a working capital requirement than the consulting awards or the government awards, kind of things so you can think of it in that sense. Margins, again, we're talking about margin rate improvement next year to the tune of 25 or 50 basis points. That will come from across the board execution improvement. New business carries with it more attractive margins and challenges for us to be able to deliver those margins.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add that as we  assess the desirability to pursue a new business opportunity, the capital intensity is taken into consideration and how that fits in our overall corporate fixture. There's deals that we're working or walking away from time to
componenttext: I would just add that as we  assess the desirability to pursue a new business opportunity, the capital intensity is taken into consideration and how that fits in our overall corporate fixture. There's deals that we're working or walking away from time to time because they're too capital intensive. So that's right in our forefront and we pay attention to that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Srini Anantha with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll move on to Srini Anantha with Oppenheimer.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, obviously, you've talked about a certain portion of future growth would be coming from acquisitions. Could you just say, where does that list in the priorities as you look at fiscal year '11, especially with operations now being stabilized? And just
componenttext: Mike, obviously, you've talked about a certain portion of future growth would be coming from acquisitions. Could you just say, where does that list in the priorities as you look at fiscal year '11, especially with operations now being stabilized? And just one question on the bookings, is there any reason given your comments about pipeline that your bookings for the next fiscal quarter would be less than $2 billion?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk about the acquisition first. As I said at the Investors Day, we're back in the acquisition mode. We feel very good about our balance sheet, feel it strong, feel the cash flows are consistent and solid. So we put a target out there of abo
componenttext: Well, let me talk about the acquisition first. As I said at the Investors Day, we're back in the acquisition mode. We feel very good about our balance sheet, feel it strong, feel the cash flows are consistent and solid. So we put a target out there of about 2% to 3% growth as a result of acquisition, and that's 2% to 3% a year. It may not necessarily all happen in one year in a 2% to 3% or it may overlap a little bit. But just in general terms, that's our target, 2% to 3% of acquisitive growth per year and we're active on that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang with JPMorgan.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an idea what percent of revenues coming from NHS now and is there a reason why we assume that it could contract a bit in fiscal '11?
componenttext: Can you give us an idea what percent of revenues coming from NHS now and is there a reason why we assume that it could contract a bit in fiscal '11?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, I cannot give you that visibility as a result of our contract terms. So I apologize but unfortunately, we couldn't get into that.
componenttext: Unfortunately, I cannot give you that visibility as a result of our contract terms. So I apologize but unfortunately, we couldn't get into that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Then on free cash flows, is there a chance that we might see a little smoother performance quarter to quarter next year with free cash flow?
componenttext: Then on free cash flows, is there a chance that we might see a little smoother performance quarter to quarter next year with free cash flow?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Tien, we're certainly working on it. It takes some time to obviously restructure contracts and re-orient milestones et cetera, et cetera, but we're working on it very diligently. And I'm not going to stand up here and preach success at this moment. But in
componenttext: Tien, we're certainly working on it. It takes some time to obviously restructure contracts and re-orient milestones et cetera, et cetera, but we're working on it very diligently. And I'm not going to stand up here and preach success at this moment. But in future quarters over time, I think you'll see dramatic change in our quarterly cash flow profile. How quickly that comes, I'm not quite ready to commit specifically.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason Kupferberg with UBS has our next question.
componenttext: Jason Kupferberg with UBS has our next question.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Steve Fordham for Jason. During the last call, you guys mentioned that we should expect the lower CapEx run rate going forward. I'm just wondering what part of CapEx are you guys targeting to lower? Is it traditional property equipment or
componenttext: This is actually Steve Fordham for Jason. During the last call, you guys mentioned that we should expect the lower CapEx run rate going forward. I'm just wondering what part of CapEx are you guys targeting to lower? Is it traditional property equipment or is it software and hardware [ph] contracts?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Initially, it would be more oriented, as Mike said, toward some of the outsourcing opportunities that are extremely capital intensive with very deferred and longer-term recoveries of the initial investment. Those are the kinds of things we're looking at e
componenttext: Initially, it would be more oriented, as Mike said, toward some of the outsourcing opportunities that are extremely capital intensive with very deferred and longer-term recoveries of the initial investment. Those are the kinds of things we're looking at extremely carefully and probably the primary targeting area in terms of reduced CapEx spending. And we're also looking at variations with the clients on how we can minimize CapEx investments and that includes obvious things like leasing opportunities and more innovative ways of refreshing assets, et cetera, et cetera. So it's across the spectrum but outsourcing contracts would probably get the primary focus.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.
componenttext: We have a question from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just real quick on the NHS contract. I know we're multiple years into this deal and I think it's generally been a cash-draining contract so far. Could you give us an update on what type of cash flow you're expecting from NHS in fiscal '10. And if you can'
componenttext: Just real quick on the NHS contract. I know we're multiple years into this deal and I think it's generally been a cash-draining contract so far. Could you give us an update on what type of cash flow you're expecting from NHS in fiscal '10. And if you can't specify the exact number, can you just give us a direction on whether it's positive or negative? And then assuming the NHS program gets truncated and there's clearly some political momentum behind that idea, will that affect at all your longer-term financial targets for margin expansion and free cash flow improvement in any way?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Rod, let me take the first part of it and I'll let Mike Laphen address the long term aspect of NHS. Relative to the cash flow, cash flow performance of the program FY '10, we will be cash neutral by the end of the year on NHS. Now obviously, if you follow
componenttext: Rod, let me take the first part of it and I'll let Mike Laphen address the long term aspect of NHS. Relative to the cash flow, cash flow performance of the program FY '10, we will be cash neutral by the end of the year on NHS. Now obviously, if you followed it, as you have, our detailed 10-Q filings that are investment in NHS through the first two quarters has increased. You also note that when you read this particular queue for the third quarter, there is another modest increase in our investment in the NHS program. By year end, we expect to be back to about where we were at the beginning of this year or the end of last year. The program is coming through the development cycle. It will turn into more of the, obviously, the delivery and non-development phase of the program. But let me throw it back to Mike to color the NHS program.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Rod, I guess, I would just say, we have no reason to change our projections and guidance that we gave at the Investors Day in terms of growth and margin improvement. If anything, we've put another quarter in the record books and it points to that directio
componenttext: Rod, I guess, I would just say, we have no reason to change our projections and guidance that we gave at the Investors Day in terms of growth and margin improvement. If anything, we've put another quarter in the record books and it points to that direction and as we said, we're forecasting for the fourth quarter and the full year, if you could point in that direction. I think we continue to make excellent progress on the NHS. It's getting more and more embedded into the NHS system and I think that this is going to continue on in somewhat reduced way. But at this point, we have no reason to believe that we need to change the guidance we've given the Street relative to it.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-on on that, I mean with your free cash flow being cited as above your plan year to date, and since NHS is on track and you're getting at least a five-day reduction in DSOs, shouldn't that put your free cash flow in fiscal '10 above you
componenttext: Just a quick follow-on on that, I mean with your free cash flow being cited as above your plan year to date, and since NHS is on track and you're getting at least a five-day reduction in DSOs, shouldn't that put your free cash flow in fiscal '10 above your net income rather than just that of kind of a 90% mark?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: It might. We'll see how the fourth quarter comes out.
componenttext: It might. We'll see how the fourth quarter comes out.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

componenttext: I think we're ready to close down now, and I wonder if I can pass the call over to Mike Laphen for his closing remarks.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

componenttext: Thank you, Bryan, and thank you, everyone for participating. Again, as Mike said in his opening remarks, we obviously adjusted the starting time for this meeting and we'd appreciate your feedback on whether that works for you or against you. We did some initial soundings and it sounded like it would work better for the community. Though we're, I think you can hear from our tone, we're pleased with the third quarter. We look forward to concluding fourth quarter and closing the books on a successful fiscal year '10 and looking forward to fiscal year '11 on a positive note. With that, I'll conclude and talk to you in May. Thank you very much.
