headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you gave us a good update on the NHS contract and I think you’d said it’s tracking about 2% of revenue flattish year-over-year. Just for the sake of analysis, is it fair to just take the North American public services margin and apply to that 2%
componenttext:
Mike, you gave us a good update on the NHS contract and I think you’d said it’s tracking about 2% of revenue flattish year-over-year. Just for the sake of analysis, is it fair to just take the North American public services margin and apply to that 2% to get a sense of what the overall EPS exposure is on that contract? Just really to get a sense for magnitude if you will of earnings exposure given all the uncertainty over there?
And then secondly, as you look out into the second half of the year and how you’ve guided for the fiscal year. Are you assuming it stays relatively flat or are you kind of factoring in some of the cuts if you will that were talked about on the last call as well as the updates that have happened over the course of the quarter?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of our forecast, what we have included in there is our best estimate or projection at this time as I noted in the discussion, we are in negotiations and discussions with the client trying to best understand what their needs are given that s
componenttext:
Well, in terms of our forecast, what we have included in there is our best estimate or projection at this time as I noted in the discussion, we are in negotiations and discussions with the client trying to best understand what their needs are given that some of their budgetary constraints as they have been quite public about.
So, all I can tell you is we’re using the best information we have right now to go forward with our projection. It couldn’t have been impacted, certainly could be somewhat, but right now, we think we’re in a pretty good projection.
Relative to the margin, we don’t and won’t discuss specific margins on any contract, but even more so on this when we’re precluded from doing so. I know that that needs a little bit of variability in the formula, but that’s essentially where we are fortunately.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. So, the absence of any specific commentary from you though would be unreasonable to use, the North American margins just to get a sense for the magnitude of the exposure on the contract?
componenttext: Right. So, the absence of any specific commentary from you though would be unreasonable to use, the North American margins just to get a sense for the magnitude of the exposure on the contract?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I’m just not going to go there.
componenttext: No, I’m just not going to go there.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the North American business, I think you gave some clarity on this in terms of some of your commentary, but the bookings last year, I don’t have the number in front of me, but I think they were down and you are still projecting growth
componenttext: Okay. And then on the North American business, I think you gave some clarity on this in terms of some of your commentary, but the bookings last year, I don’t have the number in front of me, but I think they were down and you are still projecting growth this year. Is actually the growth rate looks it even decelerated a little bit, I guess in easier comps, relative to last quarter and the first quarter. Is the reason for your optimism around that business, the fact that these bookings don’t include some of these contracts the protester contract as well as the IDIQ contracts that that don’t get factored in, but in fact will start contributing in the second half of the year?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our optimism is really predicated on a couple items, on pretty much what you’ve touched. Number one, is two significant programs that have been signed up in protest for an over a year have been freed up and they will begin to contribute immediat
componenttext:
I think our optimism is really predicated on a couple items, on pretty much what you’ve touched. Number one, is two significant programs that have been signed up in protest for an over a year have been freed up and they will begin to contribute immediately. So that’s a positive in and of itself.
Incremental to that, I identified several major contracts including the Department of Missile Defense Agency and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency where we don’t announce the full value of those contracts because they are IDIQ contracts. But we know there is a considerable backlog and pipeline there within those contacts and expect that they hit fairly quickly. So with the visibility we have, we think there is a good opportunity for some uplift to come in the second half as these combinations of contracts come online.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe Mike, just two quick ones for you. The first is that in terms of the free cash flow, you’re obviously getting good growth just from earnings alone, but as you mentioned you’ve got growth coming from working capital. I think you’ve been getting
componenttext: Maybe Mike, just two quick ones for you. The first is that in terms of the free cash flow, you’re obviously getting good growth just from earnings alone, but as you mentioned you’ve got growth coming from working capital. I think you’ve been getting growth from working capital for several quarters. What happens when that tailwind starts to abate, I mean can you get into a normalized path where you’re getting your growth in cash flow, primarily from earnings and still ahead of that 90% target that you’ve laid out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, David, it depends on the future mix of business. If one can assume for the moment that there won’t be a violent swing in the mix of business or swings between the three segments, which are more or less capital intensive that are dependi
componenttext:
Well, obviously, David, it depends on the future mix of business. If one can assume for the moment that there won’t be a violent swing in the mix of business or swings between the three segments, which are more or less capital intensive that are depending on which business we are talking about. I think, it’s like how high it’s up and we’re going to keep working on the balance sheet, keep grinding. We have still significant room to improve in the receivables alone regardless of the business mix.
So, right now, free cash flow has a high correlation with our net earnings and I think prospectively as we continue to work the equation as that shouldn’t change significantly. We may hit a quarter, for example, where they might be an abnormal free cash flow or an abnormal investment requirement, if you will, CapEx spend or something like that. I can’t tell you when that would be, but startup on new outsourcing contracts might cause those kind of perturbations, but over the long haul, I think we can still keep generating 90% plus and still keep investing where we need to invest both in capital equipment as well as technology.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we’ll hear from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And next we’ll hear from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all the color on the financials and the numbers. I wanted to dig in a little bit more in detail, some of this was covered more broadly I think earlier in the call, but within NPS DOD revs was a little late, down sequentially, which is fairly un
componenttext: Thanks for all the color on the financials and the numbers. I wanted to dig in a little bit more in detail, some of this was covered more broadly I think earlier in the call, but within NPS DOD revs was a little late, down sequentially, which is fairly unusual in terms of seasonality and compared to last year. So, can you talk about what’s going on specifically there outside of the general stuff that we’re hearing about what the government is doing? And how you expect DOD to track going forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, we are holding to our projection on what we see for the NPS for the current fiscal year, and that’s mid to upper single digits. We see a path to that to those numbers. It’s fortunate to win a number of excellent opportunities. And we’ve f
componenttext:
Right now, we are holding to our projection on what we see for the NPS for the current fiscal year, and that’s mid to upper single digits. We see a path to that to those numbers. It’s fortunate to win a number of excellent opportunities. And we’ve finally broken through some key programs that were in protest and were expected to contribute significantly to our revenue, although that was delayed again this past quarter. So, that’s a big part of why growth number isn’t more aggressive than it is.
Going forward a year up or more, I think we’ll see some level of incremental pressure, and I wouldn’t predict at this point but maybe it will be more towards the midpoint of single digits and the upper and mid-single. But we don’t have the transparency or the visibility yet into some of the Gates programs to be totally predictable in that. But I think you can assume that there is going to be some downward pressure there.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. I want to add something to what Mike said. I think it was in this morning’s journal, but it may have been yesterday where Gates clarified the fact that he intended to reduce spending in certain program areas to the tune of ab
componenttext: Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. I want to add something to what Mike said. I think it was in this morning’s journal, but it may have been yesterday where Gates clarified the fact that he intended to reduce spending in certain program areas to the tune of about $100 million, but he also said he wasn’t reducing the overall defense budget and he expected to take those savings for the programs that he was operating on and plough those back into other DOD initiatives. So, again, we don’t have clarity or visibility on where that’s going to be. But certainly mission-critical will be part of that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add Adam is, while we may see some downward pressure on the defense in long-term, I think at least under the current administration we may also see some uplift in the civilian agency areas, particularly in healthcare and so forth.
componenttext: The other thing I would add Adam is, while we may see some downward pressure on the defense in long-term, I think at least under the current administration we may also see some uplift in the civilian agency areas, particularly in healthcare and so forth. And we’re extremely well positioned there. So, I think we’re a bit bliss that we have such a balanced portfolio across all of the government spending.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that’s great color. Continuing with NPS, and I have one question on MSS for a second, but just on NPS, could you give us an idea what’s going on, on the ground, I mean, Obama is making some pretty strong statements, so is Gates and he comes back
componenttext: Okay, that’s great color. Continuing with NPS, and I have one question on MSS for a second, but just on NPS, could you give us an idea what’s going on, on the ground, I mean, Obama is making some pretty strong statements, so is Gates and he comes back and qualifies them little bit. But what kind of projects are being funded or seems to be better positioned to be continued, and how is it consulting, is it integration or is it cost control and how should we segment which kinds of projects are doing better than others?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, the first thing that you should consider Adam is I think you’re going to continue to see a consistent and probably even more aggressive move for the short term IDIQ contracts, as opposed to the larger scale programs. Quite frankly, that could i
componenttext:
I think, the first thing that you should consider Adam is I think you’re going to continue to see a consistent and probably even more aggressive move for the short term IDIQ contracts, as opposed to the larger scale programs. Quite frankly, that could impact our announced values that you see, because we don’t include the task order values until they are specifically announced. Now, that doesn’t mean that we’re still going to be bullish on our future, we would, but it will come in smaller bites.
I think the other thing that we are hearing on the ground which we’re frankly quite pleased about, is this administration is much more eager to embrace commercial best practices and commercial ways of doing business, and again with the way we strive at both commercial and public sector, we are ideally suited for that and we are engaged in a lot of discussion across the administration at numerous levels on how they might best approach that initiative.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: At MSS, business a little bit in 2Q was down after being up in the fourth quarter, which is surprising given Zurich and Raytheon wins, what’s driving the growth performance within MSS and are you again as equally confident in MSS as you are in NPS for t
componenttext: At MSS, business a little bit in 2Q was down after being up in the fourth quarter, which is surprising given Zurich and Raytheon wins, what’s driving the growth performance within MSS and are you again as equally confident in MSS as you are in NPS for the year in terms of growth?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes we are Adam. Let me first say it takes a little while to go from contract award to seeing a significant uptick in the revenue stream. There is obviously…
componenttext: Yes we are Adam. Let me first say it takes a little while to go from contract award to seeing a significant uptick in the revenue stream. There is obviously…

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it more of a ramp delay, kind of, thing or just a -?
componenttext: Is it more of a ramp delay, kind of, thing or just a -?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly. That’s why we are pointing towards the second half and saying that you will really see the effect of those wins ramping up in the second half.
componenttext: Yes, exactly. That’s why we are pointing towards the second half and saying that you will really see the effect of those wins ramping up in the second half.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final question, and then I will turn it over, is on NHS and I appreciate the fact that you can’t say how big it is or what the margins on it but it does come up a lot with investors and rightly or wrongly I think the last taste in people’s mouth in
componenttext: My final question, and then I will turn it over, is on NHS and I appreciate the fact that you can’t say how big it is or what the margins on it but it does come up a lot with investors and rightly or wrongly I think the last taste in people’s mouth in the sector are big government contract within MCI and that this is anywhere close to that kind of deal, but if you could just address the two points that’s around the NHS contract that I think people have the biggest hang up on, just not that we are expecting it, but if it were to end today, what would be the impact in terms of your recoverability if that is such a word, in terms of growth and margins going forward? Would you on the hook for anything or is it generating positive cash and also if it ended today, maybe we take away from growth but it wouldn’t be a huge loss like, just try to put some borders around what the potential impact could be?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, if it was to happen today, the top line would be impacted. I would say, if it happened today which by the way I have no indication whatsoever that that is the expectation. I would just say more than likely we would wind up in disputes and there
componenttext:
Obviously, if it was to happen today, the top line would be impacted. I would say, if it happened today which by the way I have no indication whatsoever that that is the expectation. I would just say more than likely we would wind up in disputes and therefore, I don’t think either one of us wants that to happen. I think both of us want to make sure that this program goes forward and delivers what we all expect it to deliver.
So I’m not going to speculate on how disputes will come out or anything like that, but I’m sure the government would take one position, we’ll take another position, but I think we’re both working cooperatively to assure that that doesn’t happen and that we’re moving forward within the affordable envelope that the NHS has.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we’ll hear from Ed Caso with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And next we’ll hear from Ed Caso with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: You reiterated your operating margin improvement assumptions. I’m wondering if you could give us some factors, where you expect it to come from, whether it’s gross, whether it’s G&A, sales side or offshore? Can you give us a sense on what the key fa
componenttext: You reiterated your operating margin improvement assumptions. I’m wondering if you could give us some factors, where you expect it to come from, whether it’s gross, whether it’s G&A, sales side or offshore? Can you give us a sense on what the key factors are?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: The quick first answer is, of course, is all of the above. To tick them up, we are driving offshore, if you will, for a significant amount of our commercial work. We are as you could see from our first quarter results operating on the G&A line which you
componenttext:
The quick first answer is, of course, is all of the above. To tick them up, we are driving offshore, if you will, for a significant amount of our commercial work. We are as you could see from our first quarter results operating on the G&A line which you’re looking at as the corporate G&A, but we’re obviously working hard on the G&A line. Frankly, as we control CapEx spending, in future quarters that would translate into lower depreciation and amortization expense in the P&L which again is a byproduct and a benefit of other improvement we’re incorporating in the business.
So, it’s a constant and relentless drive across all the elements of cost. I talked in the past about we’ve got a very active program in reducing our facilities footprint, trimming excess facilities, doing more a hoteling kind of an approach with our consulting workforce, renegotiating leases for better terms I mean the real estate market presents a significant opportunity and we have a considerable amount of leased office space where landlords are happy to retain us and more than willing to work with us to improve the cost profile and those kinds of things. So, longwinded response it’s everywhere.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like most of it is from the G&A line. Is there any assumption on improved pricing? And give us a sense maybe what’s happening into gross margin line?
componenttext: It sounds like most of it is from the G&A line. Is there any assumption on improved pricing? And give us a sense maybe what’s happening into gross margin line?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, as pricing would be generally speaking what the marketplace offers and presents in terms of competitiveness and so on and so forth. So, it’s incumbent upon us to be more efficient in terms of the delivery of our products and services, and tha
componenttext: Obviously, as pricing would be generally speaking what the marketplace offers and presents in terms of competitiveness and so on and so forth. So, it’s incumbent upon us to be more efficient in terms of the delivery of our products and services, and that’s obviously another aspect of what we work on improving our delivery process, our performance under our long-term contracts. There is an endless drive obviously to be more efficient in the execution of our backlog work. We have a huge backlog that presents a significant margin improvement opportunity that is foremost in our minds and on the minds of our operators.

componenttext: And then my second question, just we haven’t really touched much on the BSS unit. It was a little bit soft, can you give us a little bit update on what you’re seeing in terms of more discretionary project base work, has it starting to pick up? Are larger deals starting to get signed or is it still sort of comparable to what it might have been last quarter?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’d say we’re certainly not seeing the larger projects in any significant way, so that turn hasn’t been made yet. I would say that the pipeline is looking better and the quality of the pipeline is looking better. So, it leads us to believe that barr
componenttext:
I’d say we’re certainly not seeing the larger projects in any significant way, so that turn hasn’t been made yet. I would say that the pipeline is looking better and the quality of the pipeline is looking better. So, it leads us to believe that barring again macroeconomic considerations or significant changes in the economy coming that we’re going to see a pick up in the second half of this year relative to the projects. There is a lot more activity out there than there has been. I don’t think people are going to commit to big projects until some of the uncertainty is eliminated from the broader picture, including the whole tax picture.
I just think there is too many uncertainties out there for people to go out with big types of capital spending, including in the capital spending of major capital IT projects. So I think they’re going to continue to be bite-size, but we’re seeing more of the medium size opportunities building out there. So we do see a build in the pipeline.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010

componenttext: Karl, to remind you, BSS is down principally because of the divestiture of the business that I spoke of that occurred in the second quarter of last year. So if you adjust out the impact of the divestiture, BSS is actually up 2.5%.

componenttext: I’d just add that a considerable robust activity is around the whole application space and as I mentioned that was double-digit for us the first quarter, and we expect that to continue in the double-digit area and probably be even more robust. So in the application and management space, that’s quite buoyant.

Well, we gave the predicted pipeline numbers for the remainder of fiscal year, I believe. But just to give a little bit more color for our managed services sector which is the outsourcing, first of all, I said the application’s management fees that’s within that is quite buoyant and we’re excited about that.
I would say the virtualization cloud is driving a lot of activity in interest, and our outsourcing opportunities that we’re seeing a significant uptick in outsourcing opportunities that we would hope to close in the second half. And then I would bounce back to the NPS side where we continue to see a very robust pipeline, again that I think we’ve already given you the overall numbers on that but that goes across a pretty board spectrum for us that I again highlighted the number of places towards the details.

componenttext: And then just one last question from my standpoint. headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s the macro environment that can swing thing significantly one way or the other. I mean if we go into a deflationary period or if we do in fact slip into a double-dip recession or the uncertainty increases even more than it is now and busines
componenttext: I think it’s the macro environment that can swing thing significantly one way or the other. I mean if we go into a deflationary period or if we do in fact slip into a double-dip recession or the uncertainty increases even more than it is now and business becomes even more nervous than they currently are, I think that’s really what’s going to impact our top line more than anything else. I think the government reaction, say the UK, who is actively undertaking their process as we speak, I’d say the U.S. government. I think that will be much slower process in terms of how that rolls out and how that impacts us. So I think those markets are a little bit different, but yes, really the macro picture is the highest uncertainty for us.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2011 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the conference over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ple
componenttext: Good day everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2011 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the conference over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Well, good morning everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC's earnings call for the first quarter of our fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you've had a good opportunity to review them.Wi
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Well, good morning everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC's earnings call for the first quarter of our fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you've had a good opportunity to review them.
With me today are Mike Laphen, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Mancuso, our Chief Financial Officer. As usual, this call is being webcast at csc.com, and we've also posted slides to our website to accompany our discussion.
On Slide 2, there is a reminder that statements made during this call that are not historical facts may be considered forward-looking statements under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties which could cause actual results to differ materially. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties is contained in the company's filings with the SEC. The copies of these filings are available from the SEC, from our website and from our Investor Relations Department. 
Slide 3 acknowledges that CSC's presentation includes certain non-GAAP financial measures. In accordance with SEC rules, a reconciliation of these metrics to GAAP metrics is included in the tables of the earnings release and in the appendix to our slides. Both documents are available for your review at the Investor Relations section of the CSC website. 
Finally, I'd like to remind our listeners that CSC assumes no obligation to update the information presented on this conference call, except of course as required by law.  Now if you'd kindly move to Slide #4, I'm pleased to turn the call over to Mike Laphen.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well thank you, Bryan, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. And thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter financial results. My remarks this morning will focus on three areas: First, I will share with you my assessment of our first
componenttext:
Well thank you, Bryan, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. And thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter financial results. My remarks this morning will focus on three areas: First, I will share with you my assessment of our first quarter financial performance. Second, I'll address some topics we believe are on the minds of our investors and finally, I will provide our overall sense of the broader marketplace and the resulting implications on our business for the remainder of our fiscal year '11. As usual, when I finish, Mike Mancuso will add some color and detail to our numbers. And then we'll move on to take your questions.
On our last call, we reported very strong fiscal year-end performance and indicated that we were optimistic about our prospects for the new fiscal year. We can now report a solid result for our first quarter, and that our optimism for continued improvement this fiscal year remains intact. 
The highlights of our first quarter are shown on Slide 5. In line with our expectations, we continued to see top line improvement this quarter, achieving positive growth year-over-year as reported. Both our North American Public Sector and our Managed Services Sector reported 2.2% increases in revenue. Our Business Solutions & Services Sector revenues experienced a slight decline of 2%. However, net of the effects from a disposition, it also grew by 2.5%. So all three lines of businesses demonstrated top line growth.
Our long-term profitability program again delivered results. Operating income increased by 5.7% and operating margin rose to 7.1%, a 32 basis point improvement year-over-year. With the improved operational performance, EPS grew at a rate greater than revenue and increased to $0.91, up 7% year-over-year. This positive EPS result was achieved despite an effective tax rate increase of some 300 basis points year-over-year. 
Cash performance also improved, as we reduced the variability of our quarterly cash flows. While cash flow was negative, as is the norm for our first quarter, free cash flow improved by some $144 million year-over-year. This improvement reflects our continued focus and success in cash management across the corporation.
On the new business front, bookings were $3.2 billion, down $300 million year-over-year. Continuing delays in the U.S. government's acquisition process were the primary cause of the lower bookings number. Some particularly noteworthy bookings included important wins at UBS, the Swiss financial services giant, and at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration or NOAA. UBS is now one of our largest outsourcing relationships in the banking and capital markets industry. At NOAA, our North American Public Sector was awarded a prestigious $317 million high-performance computing contract in support of NOAA's environmental modeling program to improve the accuracy of global and regional climate models. These wins, as well as other recent startups including Zurich, will contribute to our revenue profile in the second half.
Turning to Slide 6. I would now like to discuss the investor topics I referenced earlier. There have been numerous media reports on the potential effect that growing deficits might have on government spending. In addition, there have been several announced directives related to government contracting in general, and some on IT specifically. Since the U.S. government is our largest Public Sector customer, I will start there. 
On the civil side of the federal business, the new OMB or Office of Management and Budget directive on IT reform focuses on several areas including financial systems and high-risk IT programs. Of the 30 financial systems targeted for review, CSC has two monosized [ph] (19:49) programs. They are the IRS integrated financial system, which is in production and highly regarded, and a new startup with the Department of Agriculture. Both programs are scheduled for government review within the next 30 days. Impact, if any, should be minimal, and second half revenues for these two programs combined amount to less than $10 million.
In regard to high-risk IT programs, we believe there should be improvements in federal IT acquisition and management practices, and agree that OMB's efforts to reform these regulations and processes are important. Plans for agency reviews are still being formulated, so the assessment process is still in its early stages of definition. As troubled programs are restructured to introduce commercial IT practices, we see potential business opportunities for CSC. We believe CSC's strength in bringing commercial best practices in technology to the federal government over a wide range of successful programs gives us advantages over competitors, and we view this as a key differentiator for us in the marketplace.
Long awaited government healthcare initiatives are generating opportunity at both the federal and state levels. The Affordable Care Act is now moving into the implementation phase. This is driving an increase in contract activities across many federal civil agencies including HHS, SSA and the Treasury. In addition, both the VA and the DoD are planning major monetization efforts for their health systems. There will also be significant opportunities at the state level as mandates such as health insurance gateways must be implemented. I would note that CSC developed Health Insurance Gateway for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and it's the first of its kind in the country.
For the next several years, the outlook for the U.S. defense spending, particularly in the key areas of intelligence logistics systems support, data center consolidation and cybersecurity are positive. These are all mission critical markets in which CSC is well entrenched. Having said this, Secretary Gates has announced his goal of reducing DoD spending by $100 billion to [ph] (22:10) increased efficiency and the elimination of unnecessary programs. We've already seen the beginning of reductions in major weapons programs with more likely to come. This particular area of defense spending cutbacks is not anticipated to impact us in a material way although we expect further program reductions from Defense Secretary Gates' ongoing efficiency studies, we also believe the DoD's interest in leveraging commercial practices to improve productivity will play to our strengths. So with the high level of noise surrounding U.S. defense spending, it's important to use a filter when assessing the impacts. CSC continues to see the U.S. defense market as healthy and a solid contributor to our business.
Turning now to Europe. In the U.K., the new government is looking to achieve budget efficiencies and value for money, while improving the services they deliver to their citizens. Our business with the U.K., exclusive of NHS, is limited to about 2% of CSC revenue. Our U.K. management team has met with principal government partners, and we have offered a number of innovative proposals that could enable both parties to achieve their objectives. We anticipate these discussions to continue and expect to achieve resolution across our contract base, including the NHS program, in the September time frame.
With regard to NHS specifically, our NHS program has continued to deliver successfully through the first quarter. In primary care, our footprint has expanded with 57 new GP deployments this quarter, giving us a total of 1,350 fully operational GP systems. 16 million patient records are now expertly and accurately managed through our Primary Care Solution. I'm pleased to report that the high-profile deployment at the University Hospital at Morecambe Bay, the first acute hospital trust to operate with our Lorenzo Release 1.9 solution, successfully went live at the end of May. The earlier deployment of Bury Trust has also been updated with this latest incremental functionality.
We are proceeding with deployment preparations at our final two early-adopter trusts during our Q2 and Q3. This will complete the early adopter phase for Lorenzo Release 1.9. We would then anticipate a quickening pace of full-scale deployments. 
Outside of the U.K., our business in EMEA from a macro perspective is concentrated in the more economically robust countries including France, Germany, the Nordics and Switzerland. The euro's weakness has aided the exporting economies, especially Germany, and our businesses in France and Switzerland are healthy and growing. Only 1.2% of our business is in Southern Europe, mostly in Italy. We have little if any exposure to the national markets of Portugal, Spain, Ireland or Greece.
Across Europe, currency effects will probably produce a top line headwind for us this year. At current spot rates, CSC's fiscal year revenues will be negatively impacted by about 1%. 
Looking across the border market at our global commercial businesses, we see some signs of recovery. Pipelines are building constructively. Customers are more actively engaging in exploration of new initiatives, although their decisions are still cautious. We anticipate this activity will translate to top line uplift in our second half.
Demand for managed services is positive and we experienced an increase in RFI and RFP activity in Q1. Primary drivers are cost efficiency, globalization and increased privacy and security regulations and concerns. Developments in virtualization and cloud are driving the adaptation of new business models into forms of technology as a service, which plays to CSC's strengths. 
Demand for applications management was strong. Our revenue in this business was up over 10% year-over-year. Overall the qualified pipeline of sourcing opportunities to be awarded in fiscal year '11 stands at $12 billion, up from $11 billion year-over-year.
Within our federal market, NPS delivered positive first quarter growth of 2.2%. Importantly, two protests of significant contracts have recently been resolved, which should benefit growth in our second half. We now have the transition activities on the TSA ITIP contract, the $492 million award we won over a year ago, to begin in early September. The Army's R2-3G contract is a significant ID/IQ vehicle with a $16.4 billion ceiling. Its predecessor contract was one of our largest contract vehicles. And the lack of new task order flow over the last 18 months has been a headwind for the business. Now that this protest has been resolved, we expect task orders to begin to flow again over the next several months.
Other key first quarter wins for NPS include three significant ID/IQ contracts from the Department of State, the Missile Defense Agency and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. These vehicles have a combined ceiling of $4 billion. While we do not include CCV estimates [ph](27:42) for these wins in our new business bookings disclosure, second half revenues will benefit as task orders from these vehicles start to flow. While the frustrations of a prolonged federal procurement process persist, our federal business pipeline remains strong, with some $19 billion awards currently scheduled to be announced by the end of fiscal year '11.
Turning to Slide 7 and looking forward. Complementing our pipeline of new business opportunities is our strong backlog position. CSC's diverse portfolio of public sector and commercial business generates a substantial revenue backlog that provides stability and predictability to our financial results. Excluding short-term project revenues, our current backlog stands at approximately $42 billion and represents approximately three years of revenue, essentially evenly split between commercial and NPS. Added to this backlog, there is a substantial revenue potential from our broad portfolio of U.S. Government ID/IQ contracts. Mike Mancuso will provide additional details in his remarks.
We are reaffirming our guidance for bookings in excess of $18 billion, and top line growth of 4% to 7%, an expansion of 25 to 50 basis points for the year in the operating margin, and EPS of $5.30 to $5.40 and free cash flow greater than 90% of net income. Additionally, we are affirming a dividend of $0.15 to our shareholders of record as of the 9th of September 2010. At this point, I'd like to turn the call over to Mike Mancuso for further details on our first quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of fiscal year '11.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning ladies and gentlemen. If you'll turn to Chart 9, which should look familiar to you since it was Mike Laphen's opening chart. I am using it again because I want to strongly emphasize to all of our shareholders that as a manag
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning ladies and gentlemen. If you'll turn to Chart 9, which should look familiar to you since it was Mike Laphen's opening chart. I am using it again because I want to strongly emphasize to all of our shareholders that as a management team, we are focused on and committed to continuous improvement. And each of the financial metrics referenced on this chart have favorably, and not insignificantly, improved over the last year. And at the risk of dwelling on the macroeconomic outlook and the pace of a somewhat uncertain recovery, we are doing everything we can to improve operations and position CSC for accelerated and profitable growth, as the global economic recovery accelerates. We are controlling what we can control, competing vigorously, winning a fair share of the business that is being awarded, investing in the key growth areas of cloud computing, cybersecurity and healthcare, and enhancing our horizontal capability as evidenced by our recently announced Bass acquisition, which broadens our footprint in the chemical energy and natural resources market.
To support growth, we need a strong foundation. Mike Laphen in his opening remarks mentioned the fact that at the quarter end, we have a backlog of $42 billion. Up to now, we have not talked about our backlog or offered insight into its composition. So if you will turn to Chart 10, I'll talk about that backlog in the context of our FY '11 revenue guidance. The midpoint of our revenue guidance for FY '11 is $17 billion. If you will direct your attention to the blue-shaded area at the bottom of the pyramid, including our first quarter revenue, we see 76% of our FY '11 revenue, or roughly $13 billion, coming from existing backlog. Our shorter-term project and consulting work, which is essentially our BSS segment excluding the NHS contract, which is in backlog, is very predictable and we will produce 18% of our FY '11 revenue, which is another $3 billion. Therefore, the sum of the FY '11 revenue from backlog, plus the short-term consulting project work, gets us $16 billion, meaning that we only need generate another 6% or $1 billion from new business. We see this as quite doable, considering our pipeline and our ID/IQ portfolio. And as the top of the chart suggests, we have a new business qualified pipeline of $34 billion of FY '11 potential awards. And in addition, we also have qualified for another $5 billion of ID/IQ awards which is not in backlog, but that our track record and historical performance suggests will generate a significant number of task orders which will also help fill the FY '11 new business revenue estimate. The message from this chart is that we believe our FY '11 guidance is achievable. And further that between our NPS segment, MSS segment and the NHS contract, we have $42 billion in backlog, which equates to over three years of revenue for those businesses and provides a solid foundation for future revenue growth beyond FY '11.
Now moving on. In an attempt to address the inevitable constant currency question, we will introduce Charts 11 and 12. Chart 11 breaks down our last fiscal year's revenue by currency. With the U.S. at 63%, the British pound at 12%, Europe or the euro at 9%, Australia at 5%, and 11% of All Other. This should help frame your thinking with regard to currency exposure. And I also want to remind you, most of our currency exposure is translation risk, not cost and revenue in disparate currencies.
Now if you'll turn to Chart 12, this now takes FY '11 first quarter revenue by currency, which closely approximate the FY '10 full year numbers, and on a weighted basis using the August 9 spot rate, projects the full year potential of currency impact to be roughly one point of revenue or about $170 million. The bottom line here is that if the rates hang where they are now, we don't see a significant currency impact in FY '11.
Chart 13, revenue by line of business, shows you that NPS and MSS grew by over 2%, while BSS, comprised of consulting and project work, declined by 2%. Keep in mind that NHS is in BSS and was relatively revenue-constant year-over-year. The decline in BSS is primarily the result of the divestiture of our Hong Kong break-fix business, which was sold in the second quarter of last year.
Chart 14 displays operating income by line of business. Operating income has improved 6% overall, and you can see where the gains occurred.
Chart 15 is the comparative P&L. The key takeaways are the improvement in operating income and margin rate, lower corporate G&A and interest expense more than offsetting the higher tax rate. Applying the FY '11 higher tax rate to FY '10, would yield an 11% year-over-year growth in EPS versus the reported 7%.
Chart 16 displays selected balance sheet items year-over-year. The message here is simple: more cash, less receivables, less debt and better ratios. Speaking of receivables, if you turn to Chart 17, you can see the downward migration in days receivables continues, a result of lots of hard work with tedious attention to detail. Using a baseball analogy, it's the result of a lot of singles and stolen bases, sacrifice bunts and an occasional squeeze play. However, we are not done and we think there is still room for further improvement.
Chart 18 is selected cash flow items. Cash flow from earnings has increased. The year-over-year change in working capital was less severe than in the past, although there is some growth in CapEx. However, before someone asks the question, we do not see CapEx growing this year, and we maintain our focus on being less capital-intensive as we grow. Free cash flow was much improved over last year, as we continue our focus on reducing the seasonality of free cash. We got a very good start toward that goal.
Chart 19 reiterates our quarterly EPS guidance for the rest of the year, noting that our guidance to you for Q1 was $0.88, which we were able to exceed. But at this point, we think the ranges for the next three quarters are reasonable. 
So in summary on Chart 20, I think the words speak for themselves. We had a good start to the year. Several improvements have been recorded. Yes, there are more challenges ahead. But from our perspective, optimism abounds and we look forward to another solid year. So with that said, I'll turn it back to Bryan to begin the Q&A.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thanks, Mike. Well, that concludes our prepared remarks session. And we'll now move into the Q&A part. Operator, would you please advise our callers how they may register their questions, please?
componenttext: Okay. Well, thanks, Mike. Well, that concludes our prepared remarks session. And we'll now move into the Q&A part. Operator, would you please advise our callers how they may register their questions, please?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010

componenttext: This is Alban Gashi for Bryan Keane. Can you guys talk a little bit about how that compares to what you guys were expecting in the first quarter? I think the headwinds might be a little bit lighter now.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010

componenttext: That's correct, Alban. I think we were anticipating a little bit more headwind in the first quarter. And I think as we've all seen, particularly in the British pound for example, it's holding steady if not recovering, if you will, against the dollar. So you're correct in that supposition. We think it's a little better than we had anticipated.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: During the quarter, you guys signed a new deals and extensions including a large one with UBS. Can you talk a little bit about timing, the rollout and possible pricing and margin impact as you look forward?
componenttext: During the quarter, you guys signed a new deals and extensions including a large one with UBS. Can you talk a little bit about timing, the rollout and possible pricing and margin impact as you look forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I'll talk about the timing. The pricing and margin would be proprietary between us and UBS, obviously. But the timing is moving forward into the second half. So the revenue stream associated with UBS, you can anticipate to see beginning early in the
componenttext: Well I'll talk about the timing. The pricing and margin would be proprietary between us and UBS, obviously. But the timing is moving forward into the second half. So the revenue stream associated with UBS, you can anticipate to see beginning early in the third quarter and moving aggressively through the remainder of the year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I just guess overall on the pricing structure, any comments there? Not for UBS in particular.
componenttext: And then I just guess overall on the pricing structure, any comments there? Not for UBS in particular.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: As always, these are competitive opportunities. But the transaction was done within our framework and guidelines for returns. So we're very pleased with the deal and expect it to be a good contributor to both the top line and bottom line.
componenttext: As always, these are competitive opportunities. But the transaction was done within our framework and guidelines for returns. So we're very pleased with the deal and expect it to be a good contributor to both the top line and bottom line.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we'll hear from David Grossman with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And next we'll hear from David Grossman with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you gave us a good update on the NHS contract. And I think you had said it's tracking about 2% of revenue, flattish year-over-year. Just for the sake of analysis, is it fair to just take the North America Public Services margin and apply it to that
componenttext: Mike, you gave us a good update on the NHS contract. And I think you had said it's tracking about 2% of revenue, flattish year-over-year. Just for the sake of analysis, is it fair to just take the North America Public Services margin and apply it to that 2% to get a sense of what the overall EPS exposure is on that contract? Just really to get a sense for magnitude, if you will, of earnings exposure given all the uncertainty over there. And then secondly, as you look out into the second half of the year and how you guided for the fiscal year, are you assuming it stays relatively flat? Or are you kind of factoring in some of the cuts, if you will, that were talked about on the last call as well the updates that have happened over the course of the quarter?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of our forecast, what we have included in there is our best estimate or projection at this time. As I noted in the discussion, we are in negotiations and discussions with the client, trying to best understand what their needs are given some of th
componenttext: In terms of our forecast, what we have included in there is our best estimate or projection at this time. As I noted in the discussion, we are in negotiations and discussions with the client, trying to best understand what their needs are given some of their budgetary constraints, as they have been quite public about. So all I can tell you is we're using the best information we have right now to go forward with our projection. Could that be impacted somewhat? It certainly could be somewhat. But right now, we think we're in a pretty good projection. And relative to the margin, we don't and won't discuss specific margins on any contract. But even more so on this, when we're precluded from doing so. So I know that, that leaves a little bit of variability in the formula. But that's essentially where we are unfortunately.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, so in the absence of any specific commentary from you, though, would it be unreasonable to use the North American margin just to get a sense for the magnitude of the exposure on the contract?
componenttext: Right, so in the absence of any specific commentary from you, though, would it be unreasonable to use the North American margin just to get a sense for the magnitude of the exposure on the contract?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'm just not going to go there.
componenttext: No, I'm just not going to go there.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the North American business, and I think you gave some clarity on this in terms of some of your commentary. The bookings last year, I don't have the number in front of me but I think they were down and you were still projecting growth this yea
componenttext: And then on the North American business, and I think you gave some clarity on this in terms of some of your commentary. The bookings last year, I don't have the number in front of me but I think they were down and you were still projecting growth this year. Is the reason for that -- and actually the growth rate looks like it even decelerated a little bit against an easier comp relative to last quarter and the first quarter. Is the reason for your optimism around that business the fact that these bookings don't include some of these contracts that could in fact -- the protested contracts as well as the ID/IQ contracts -- that don't get factored in, but in fact will start contributing in the second half of the year?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our optimism is really predicated on a couple items, pretty much what you've touched. Number one is, two significant programs that have been tied up in protests for over a year have been freed up, and they will begin to contribute immediately. So
componenttext: I think our optimism is really predicated on a couple items, pretty much what you've touched. Number one is, two significant programs that have been tied up in protests for over a year have been freed up, and they will begin to contribute immediately. So that's a positive in and of itself. Incremental to that, I identified several major contracts including the State Department Missile Defense Agency and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, where we don't announce the full value of those contracts because they are ID/IQ contracts. But we know there is a considerable backlog and pipeline there within those contracts and expect that they hit fairly quickly. So with the visibility we have, we think there's a good opportunity for some uplift to come in the second half, as these combination of contracts come online.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe, Mike Mancuso, just two quick ones for you. The first is that, in terms of the free cash flow, you're obviously getting good growth just from earnings alone. But as you mentioned, you've got growth coming from working capital. And I think you've
componenttext: And maybe, Mike Mancuso, just two quick ones for you. The first is that, in terms of the free cash flow, you're obviously getting good growth just from earnings alone. But as you mentioned, you've got growth coming from working capital. And I think you've been getting growth from working capital for several quarters. What happens when that tailwind starts to abate? Can you get into a normalized spot where you're getting your growth in cash flow primarily from earnings and still hit that 90% target that you've laid out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well obviously, David, it depends on the future mix of business. If one can assume for the moment that there won't be a violent swing in the mix of business, or swings between the three segments, which are more or less capital-intense, et cetera, dependin
componenttext: Well obviously, David, it depends on the future mix of business. If one can assume for the moment that there won't be a violent swing in the mix of business, or swings between the three segments, which are more or less capital-intense, et cetera, depending on which business we're talking about. I think it's like how high is up? I mean we're going to keep working on the balance sheet, keep grinding. We have still significant room to improve in receivables alone, regardless of business mix. So right now, free cash flow has a high correlation with our net earnings and I think prospectively, as we continue to work the equation that, that shouldn't change significantly. We may hit a quarter, for example, where there may be an abnormal free cash flow or an abnormal investment requirement, if you will, CapEx spend or something like that, I can't tell you when that would be but start-up on new outsourcing contracts might cause those kind of perturbations, but over the long haul I think we can still keep generating 90%-plus and still keep investing where we need to invest, both in capital equipment as well as technology.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig in a little bit more on the details of this. It was covered more broadly, I think earlier in the call. But within NPS, DoD revs looked a little light, down sequentially, which is fairly unusual in terms of seasonality and compared to the l
componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little bit more on the details of this. It was covered more broadly, I think earlier in the call. But within NPS, DoD revs looked a little light, down sequentially, which is fairly unusual in terms of seasonality and compared to the last few years. So can you talk about what's going on specifically there outside of the general stuff that we're hearing about, what the government is doing? And how you expect DoD to track going forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're holding to our projection on what we see for the MPS for the current fiscal year. And that's mid- to upper single-digits. We see a path to those numbers. We've been fortunate to win a number of excellent opportunities. And we've finally b
componenttext: Right now, we're holding to our projection on what we see for the MPS for the current fiscal year. And that's mid- to upper single-digits. We see a path to those numbers. We've been fortunate to win a number of excellent opportunities. And we've finally broken through some key programs that were in protest and were expected to contribute significantly to our revenue, although that was delayed again this past quarter. That's a big part of why the growth number isn't more aggressive than it is. Going forward a year out or more, I think we'll see some level of incremental pressure and I wouldn't predict at this point but maybe it'll be more towards the mid-point of single digits than the upper end mid-single, but we don't have the transparency or the visibility yet into some of the Gates programs to be totally predictable in that. But I think you can assume that there is going to be some downward pressure there.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. I want to add something to what Mike said. I think it was in this morning's Journal, but it may have been yesterday, where Gates clarified the fact that he intended to reduce spending in certain program areas to the tune of abo
componenttext: Adam, this is Mike Mancuso. I want to add something to what Mike said. I think it was in this morning's Journal, but it may have been yesterday, where Gates clarified the fact that he intended to reduce spending in certain program areas to the tune of about $100 million. But he also said he wasn't reducing the overall defense budget and he expected to take those savings for the programs that he was operating on and plow those back into other DoD initiatives. So again we don't have clarity or visibility on where that's going to be. But certainly, mission-critical will be part of that.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add, Adam, is that while we may see some downward pressure on the defense in the long-term, I think at least under the current administration, we may also see some uplift in the civilian agency areas, particularly in healthcare and
componenttext: The other thing I would add, Adam, is that while we may see some downward pressure on the defense in the long-term, I think at least under the current administration, we may also see some uplift in the civilian agency areas, particularly in healthcare and so forth, and we're extremely well positioned there. So I think we're a bit blessed that we have such a balanced portfolio across all of the government spending.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continuing with NPS, and then I have one question on MSS for a second. But just on NPS, can you give us an idea of what's going on on the ground? I mean Obama's making some pretty strong statements. So is Gates, then he comes back and qualifies them a lit
componenttext: Continuing with NPS, and then I have one question on MSS for a second. But just on NPS, can you give us an idea of what's going on on the ground? I mean Obama's making some pretty strong statements. So is Gates, then he comes back and qualifies them a little bit. But what kind of projects are being funded or seem to be better positioned to be continued? And is it consulting? Is it integration? Or is it cost control? How should we segment which kinds of projects are going better than others?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think the first thing that you should consider, Adam, is I think you're going to continue to see a consistent and probably even more aggressive move to the short-term ID/IQ contracts as opposed to the larger-scale programs, and quite frankly that c
componenttext: Well I think the first thing that you should consider, Adam, is I think you're going to continue to see a consistent and probably even more aggressive move to the short-term ID/IQ contracts as opposed to the larger-scale programs, and quite frankly that could impact our announced values that you see because we don't include the past quarter values until they're specifically announced. Now that doesn't mean that we still wouldn't be bullish on our future, we would, but it will come in smaller bites. I think the other thing that we're hearing on the ground which we're frankly quite pleased about is this administration is much more eager to embrace commercial best practices and commercial ways of doing business. And again, with the way we've straddled both commercial and public sector, we're ideally suited for that and we're engaged in a lot of discussions across the administration at numerous levels on how they might best approach that initiative.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the MSS, you might have touched this for a second, I had to get off the call for a minute or two. But business [indiscernible] (51:40) a little bit, in 2Q it was down after being up in the fourth quarter, which is surprising given Zurich and Raytheon
componenttext: And the MSS, you might have touched this for a second, I had to get off the call for a minute or two. But business [indiscernible] (51:40) a little bit, in 2Q it was down after being up in the fourth quarter, which is surprising given Zurich and Raytheon wins. What's driving the growth performance within MSS? And are you again as equally confident in MSS as you are in NPS for the year in terms of growth?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are, Adam. Le me first say, it takes a little while to go from contract to award, to have seen the significant uptick in the revenue stream. And that's why we're pointing to the second half and saying that you will really see the effect of those w
componenttext: Yes, we are, Adam. Le me first say, it takes a little while to go from contract to award, to have seen the significant uptick in the revenue stream. And that's why we're pointing to the second half and saying that you will really see the effect of those wins ramping up in the second half.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final question, and then I'll turn it over, is on NHS and I appreciate the fact that you can't say how big it is or the margins on it. But it does come up a lot with investors. And rightly or wrongly, I think the last taste in people's mouths in the se
componenttext: My final question, and then I'll turn it over, is on NHS and I appreciate the fact that you can't say how big it is or the margins on it. But it does come up a lot with investors. And rightly or wrongly, I think the last taste in people's mouths in the sector of big government contract was NMCI, and not that this is anywhere close to that kind of deal. But if you could just address the two points that are around the NHS contract that I think people have the biggest hang-up on. If it were to end today, just not that we are expecting it but if it were to end today, what would be the impact in terms of your recoverability, if that is such a word, in terms of growth and margins going forward? Would you be on the hook for anything or is it generating positive cash flow now so if it ended today, it maybe would take away from growth but it wouldn't be a huge loss like – just try to put some borders around what the potential impact could be.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously if it was to happen today, the top line would be impacted. I would say, if it happened today -- which by the way I have no indication whatsoever that, that is the expectation -- I would just that more than likely, we would wind up in disputes. A
componenttext: Obviously if it was to happen today, the top line would be impacted. I would say, if it happened today -- which by the way I have no indication whatsoever that, that is the expectation -- I would just that more than likely, we would wind up in disputes. And therefore, I don't think either one of us wants that to happen. I think both of us will want to make sure that this program goes forward and delivers what we all expect it to deliver. So I'm not going to speculate on how disputes will come out or anything like that. But I'm sure the government would take one position, we'd take another position. But I think we're both working cooperatively to assure that, that doesn't happen and that we're moving forward within the affordable envelope that the NHS has.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010

componenttext: Next we will hear from Ed Caso with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: You reiterated your operating margin improvement assumptions. And I was wondering if you could give us some of the factors, where you expect it to come from, whether it's gross, whether it's G&A, sales side or offshore. Can you just give us a sense what t
componenttext: You reiterated your operating margin improvement assumptions. And I was wondering if you could give us some of the factors, where you expect it to come from, whether it's gross, whether it's G&A, sales side or offshore. Can you just give us a sense what the key factors are?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: The quick answer, Ed, of course is all of the above. To tick them off, we are driving offshore, if you will, for a significant amount of our commercial work. We are, as you can see from our first quarter results, operating on the G&A line. What you're loo
componenttext: The quick answer, Ed, of course is all of the above. To tick them off, we are driving offshore, if you will, for a significant amount of our commercial work. We are, as you can see from our first quarter results, operating on the G&A line. What you're looking at is corporate G&A, but we're obviously working hard on the G&A line. Frankly, as we control CapEx spending in future quarters, that would translate into lower depreciation and amortization expense in the P&L, which, again, is a byproduct and a benefit of the other improvements we're incorporating in the business. So it's a constant and relentless drive across all the elements of cost. I've talked in the past about, we've got a very active program in reducing our facilities' footprint, trimming excess facilities, doing more hoteling kind of an approach with our consulting workforce, renegotiating leases for better terms. I mean the real estate market presents a significant opportunity. And we have a considerable amount of leased office space, where landlords are happy to retain us and more than willing to work with us to improve the cost profile for those kinds of things. So long-winded response, it's everywhere.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like most of it's focused on the G&A line. Is there any assumptions on improved pricing? And give us a sense maybe what's happening at the gross margin line.
componenttext: It sounds like most of it's focused on the G&A line. Is there any assumptions on improved pricing? And give us a sense maybe what's happening at the gross margin line.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well obviously, pricing will be generally speaking what the marketplace offers and presents in terms of competitiveness and so on and so forth. So it's incumbent upon us to be more efficient in terms of the delivery of our products and services. And that'
componenttext: Well obviously, pricing will be generally speaking what the marketplace offers and presents in terms of competitiveness and so on and so forth. So it's incumbent upon us to be more efficient in terms of the delivery of our products and services. And that's obviously another aspect of what we work on, improving our delivery process, our performance under our long-term contracts. There's an endless drive obviously to be more efficient in the execution of our backlog work. We have a huge backlog that presents a significant margin improvement opportunity that is foremost in our minds and on the minds of our operators.

componenttext: We haven't really touched much on the BSS unit. It was a little bit soft. Can you give us a little update on what you're seeing in terms of the more discretionary project-based work? Is it starting to pick up? Are larger deals starting to get signed? Or is it still sort of comparable to what it might have been last quarter?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say we're certainly not seeing the larger projects in any significant way. So that turn hasn't been made yet. I would say that the pipeline is looking better, and the quality of the pipeline is looking better. So it leads us to believe that, barri
componenttext: I would say we're certainly not seeing the larger projects in any significant way. So that turn hasn't been made yet. I would say that the pipeline is looking better, and the quality of the pipeline is looking better. So it leads us to believe that, barring again macroeconomic considerations or significant changes in the economy coming, that we're going to see a pickup in the second half of this year relative to the projects. There's a lot more activity out there than there has been. I don't think people are going to commit to big projects until some of the uncertainty is eliminated from the broader picture, including the whole tax picture. I just think there's too many uncertainties out there for people to go out with big types of capital spending, and including in the capital spending major capitalized key projects. So I think they're going to continue to be bite-size, but we're seeing more of the bite-sized, more of the medium-sized opportunities building out there. So we do see a build in the pipeline.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010

componenttext: Appreciate the new disclosure on the backlog statistics. And wanted to pick up on one of the pieces of commentary there, Mike Mancuso, I think that you made. And you were talking about the short-term revenue run rate piece of the backlog and I think you used the word predictability associated with that. And it seemed on the surface at least somewhat counterintuitive since these are kind of by definition short-term projects, potentially subject to delays, cancellations, just depending on the macro environment. So just wanted to make sure we're clear on what degree of predictability truly exists in that piece of the backlog, especially with three quarters still remaining in your fiscal year.

componenttext: Well, Jason, the past is prologue. If you look at BSS this quarter, and you factor out the effect of the divestiture, BSS was relatively constant to last year. And we see enough in front of us that suggests that, that work is highly probable in our judgment.

componenttext: Well we gave the predicted pipeline numbers for the remainder of the fiscal year I believe. Is it potentially any of the factors that you might think might cause an issue on the guidance front?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's the macro environment that can swing things significantly one way or the other. I mean if we go into a deflationary period, or if we do in fact slip into a double-dip recession, or the uncertainty increases even more than it is now, and busin
componenttext: I think it's the macro environment that can swing things significantly one way or the other. I mean if we go into a deflationary period, or if we do in fact slip into a double-dip recession, or the uncertainty increases even more than it is now, and business becomes even more nervous than they currently are, I think that's really what's going to impact our top line more than anything else. I think the government reaction, save the U.K. who is actively undertaking their process as we speak; I would say the U.S. government, I think that'll be a much slower process in terms of how that rolls out and how that impacts us. So I think those markets are a little bit different. But yes, really the macro picture is I think the highest uncertainty for us.
