componenttext: Well, I think we'll continue to see some delays in procurements. I think we're going to continue to see the escalated level of protests, so unfortunately, I think that's for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, on the positive side, we've booked some tremendous business recently and we've got some of the protests behind us. So we feel that we've got a good growth profile going forward. I would think in terms of mid-single digits, with that part of our business at this point in time, were for both the second half and probably going into next fiscal year.

componenttext: Adam, to add to that, just to remind you, you've probably seen it throughout the quarter, we as Mike said, we have significant IDIQ wins in the quarter. But a very sizable amount of IDIQ awards in the quarter which, again, don't reflect in backlog yet, but still provide comfort and opportunity as we look out beyond this year.

componenttext: Joe, it's the second quarter in a row we've used this slide. If I had included the first quarter slide, you'd see that the blue area has grown a few percentage points. The top of the pyramid has shrunk a percentage points. Backlog is almost unchanged in rounding. It's still around the $42 billion in the quarter. The IDIQ potential, if you look last quarter, it was $6 billion. We've thrown a little plus sign into it at this time. That's to indicate that the amount of additional IDIQ would work that we won in the second quarter, that we're trying to refine so that we can upgrade this particular number to a more current status. So a long-winded answer, there aren't anything different, unique or whatever in this particular chart other than the top of the pyramid is shrinking.

componenttext: I know I think I heard in your remarks that you actually paid down a little bit more to debt here post the quarter but you're still sitting on a couple of billion dollars of cash. I was wondering if had any updated thoughts on balance sheet deployment for shareholder purposes here?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, et cetera. We continue to posture ourselves. As you know, we are looking at growing by internal investments, by acquisition, et cetera . So all of those factors or opportunit
componenttext: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, et cetera. We continue to posture ourselves. As you know, we are looking at growing by internal investments, by acquisition, et cetera . So all of those factors or opportunities is being cranked into our thinking. We also have a large revolver that we want to get out ourselves out from under in anticipation of which way interests rates are going to go. So I think you'll see more from us in this particular area as we rethink our debt profiles and the makeup of our debt, et cetera. And of course, as we continue to generate cash flow, that will present opportunity for us.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: We'll hear from Joseph Foresi with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I know you talked about the IDIQ's increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays in some of the government decision-making? Are these mission critical IDIQ's? Is that
componenttext: First, I know you talked about the IDIQ's increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays in some of the government decision-making? Are these mission critical IDIQ's? Is that the reason why you have confidence that they're going to come through even though they're getting side?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: There has been, if you look at the year, I think you'd see that the second quarter included significantly more IDIQ activity in general in the U.S. government versus the first quarter. There are still a number of key positions in the government that are u
componenttext: There has been, if you look at the year, I think you'd see that the second quarter included significantly more IDIQ activity in general in the U.S. government versus the first quarter. There are still a number of key positions in the government that are unfilled. By virtue of the fact they're awarding the IDIQs, that's good news. The yet to follow good news is how quickly they can turn those into specific task orders and that's where we're being conservative in the sense that the government has to move -- in the second half of the year, the government has to move more quickly and more nimble than they had in the first half of the year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I would just add that I think historically, we have called out upper single digit growth in that market. You've heard me a few moments ago referred to mid-single digits and I think that reflects our caution around what's going to happen in the IDIQs
componenttext: Joe, I would just add that I think historically, we have called out upper single digit growth in that market. You've heard me a few moments ago referred to mid-single digits and I think that reflects our caution around what's going to happen in the IDIQs and in the protest arena. So we've backed off a little bit to reflect what we see out there at this point in time.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the assumption is, that IDIQs are increasing, but you're taking a more conservative approach to the rate of which they get decided on. Am I appraising that correctly?
componenttext: So the assumption is, that IDIQs are increasing, but you're taking a more conservative approach to the rate of which they get decided on. Am I appraising that correctly?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, I think that's fair and I would say that IDIQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that's a contract vehicle of choice these days. I don't see that changing so I think we're just going to hav
componenttext: I think, yes, I think that's fair and I would say that IDIQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that's a contract vehicle of choice these days. I don't see that changing so I think we're just going to have to learn a way with this.

So just trying to get some color around how that's going to look between quarters, the third quarter and the fourth quarter. Should it be balanced equally? headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: Well, I would say in terms of the third quarter and fourth quarter, it will be more weighted to the fourth quarter than the third quarter. The pops are coming from a number of the opportunities that we have won that are coming in more directly into the revenue line. Again, that brings you back to Zürich, UBS on the commercial side and on the federal side, I referred earlier to the TSA contract coming through the transition period and now moving into the full scale. Our recent award on Social Security is a direct task quarter that will get started up shortly. So there's a lot of things in the midst there that we're expecting to contributed to that growth number that you've referred to.

componenttext: If you go back to the federal business, as we start to look at lame duck Congress and maybe the first calendar quarter of next year has the impact of Congressional committee changes, are you basically looking at a lot of spending or spending pent-up demand coming in in the early part of the next fiscal year for you? Is that how things get pushed out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say what we're reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is that the business that we have recently won and that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn't say so much pent-up, I would say
componenttext: Well, I would say what we're reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is that the business that we have recently won and that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn't say so much pent-up, I would say it's the business that we've captured most recently. We've done quite well in the marketplace there. Looking past of that, I think it would be difficult to project what the new Congress is going to do and how they're going to square with the administration on federal spending. So I think we have good visibility in the second half of this year going into the first half of next year, but I think I'll have to revisit that at this point.

And don't think -- and they are very confident. You wont see that kind of behavior repeat itself. Certainly, it won't in the Nordics because the people aren't there any more.

componenttext: Well, I'd give you this input, Jason. I think that forecast is still a reasonable expectation of our aspirations and expectations. We'll probably come out to this rate sometime in the first quarter of next calendar year with some sort of investors day event that we would share with you the outcome of our efforts on the strategic plan and projections.

componenttext: Well, I'm going to speak for the board and how they think philosophically. I think we have a robust business and we will continue to be robust business. headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to the CSC fiscal year 2011 second quarter earnings call. Today’s call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I’d like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Pl
componenttext: Good day, everyone and welcome to the CSC fiscal year 2011 second quarter earnings call. Today’s call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I’d like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC’s earnings call for the second quarter of fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you had a good opportunity to review them.With me tod
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC’s earnings call for the second quarter of fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you had a good opportunity to review them.
With me today are Mike Laphen, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Mancuso, our Chief Financial Officer. As usual, the call is being webcast at csc.com and we’ve also posted slides to our Web site to accompany our discussion.
Moving to slide number 2, you’ll see a reminder that statements made during this call that are not historical facts may be considered forward-looking statements under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially.
Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties is contained in the company’s filings with the SEC. Copies of these filings are available from the SEC, from our Web site, and from our Investor Relations department.
On slide number 3 you see our acknowledgement that CSC’s presentation includes certain non-GAAP financial measures. In accordance with SEC rules, a reconciliation of these metrics to GAAP metrics is included in the tables of the earnings release and in the appendix to our slides. Both documents are available for your review at the Investor Relations section of the CSC Web site.
Finally, I’d like to remind our listeners that CSC assumes no obligation to update the information presented on this conference call, except, of course, as required by law.
Now, if you kindly move to slide number four, I am pleased to turn the call over to Mike Laphen.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bryan. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our financial results for the second quarter. We ended our last earnings call indicating that we expected our second quarter revenue to be similar to th
componenttext:
Thank you, Bryan. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our financial results for the second quarter. We ended our last earnings call indicating that we expected our second quarter revenue to be similar to that of the first quarter and that the majority of this year’s growth would occur in the second half.
Consistent with that earlier view, we delivered modest sequential revenue growth in our second quarter. However, ongoing market improvements, the resolution of a protest on some key public sector awards and the ramp-up of new business initiated in the first half, all reinforce our belief that we will experience meaningful top line growth in our second half.
On the new business front, bookings strengthened to $4.5 billion for the quarter and $7.7 billion for the first half. Based on this first half performance as well as current activity we’ve increased our full year bookings estimate by $500 million.
Across our global commercial businesses, we see definite signs of recovery. Pipelines are building constructively, customers are actively engaging in the exploration of new initiatives, and most importantly buying decisions are being made.
Business utilization and billing rates have improved, and demand for services has increased. Our Consulting pipelines are robust and total three times trailing 12 months revenue.
Win rates remained strong, indicating market acceptance of our vertical and consulting solutions and traction for our BPO and industry focused value propositions.
Accordingly, BSS delivered second quarter year-over-year growth of 6% net of M&A and in constant currency. We expect this growth to continue, if not accelerate in the second half.
Demand for outsourcing services remains positive. MSS revenues increased 2% for the quarter and 2.1% for the half in constant currency. We expect this growth to continue in the second half.
The demand for application management services is particularly strong, and we project that this segment of the business will grow at low double-digit rates year-over-year. The outsourcing pipeline for qualified opportunities scheduled for award by the close of our fiscal year ‘11 $10 to $12 billion, driving our optimism for strong second half bookings.
We are particularly pleased to start off our third quarter by welcoming VF Corporation, the world’s largest apparel company as a new CSC client. Demand for cloud services continues across our markets, and we achieved a number of significant accomplishments.
First, we successfully transitioned over 15,000 users across 36 of the city of Los Angeles’s 40 departments through our Google-based cloud platform. We also recently announced our win on the State of California program for Microsoft BPOS cloud services.
Additionally, we were selected by AMP one of Australia’s leading wealth management companies to implement our cloud based solution for email and collaborative services. This solution is based on the debug technology resulting from our announced alliance with the DCE coalition, a collaboration of CISCO, EMC and VMware.
For our groundbreaking implementation of cloud based to all of services to 28,000 Royal Mail Group employees CSC just received a National Outsourcing Association’s award for innovation in outsourcing. These accomplishments evidence CSC’s leadership position in the implementation of clod services across both the public and private sectors.
Within our cyber business, we won several new contracts having a combined TCV of $50 million. We are continuing to see a growing pipeline of cyber opportunities across both the public and commercial sectors.
The strength in our portfolio of fiber IP and to expand into some new market segments within the world of cyber, we’ve recently completed the strategic acquisition of a small but important cyber company VRL. This transaction has already generated considerable positive discussion within the community.
Our Federal Sector business MPS delivered strong second quarter bookings totaling approximately $2.9 billion which provides a good foundation for second half growth. These second quarter new business bookings included over $600 million of new TCV across the federal healthcare market space with wins at the health and human services centers for Medicare and Medicaid services, the National Institutes of Health, the Department of Defense Health Affairs and the Department of Labor Office Of Workers’ Compensation Programs.
Other important second quarter NPS wins totaling over $1 billion in TCV include deliver orders for the Department of State visa support services in Mexico, the U.S. Army Flight School XXI, IT infrastructure services for a major intelligence agency and an important win at the Social Security Agency for information technology support.
In addition to this solid first half bookings results, the NPS pipeline remains strong with $18 billion of qualified opportunities that are scheduled to be awarded over the next 12 months, $9 billion of which is scheduled for award by the end of CSC’s fiscal year.
Our constructive view of NPS growth in the second half is also based on the resolution of two important protests including the TSA ITIP program. Work finally started on this program in September and it’s now in its late stages of the planned 90-day transition phase.
I would now like to provide some updates to several of the investor topics of interest we discussed during our last earnings call. With respect to our business with the U.S. federal government, we divested at the end of the quarter a subsidiary of NPS, Mission Solutions Engineering Inc. resolving government concerns of conflicts of interest with other current CSC programs at the Missile Defense Agency and the U.S. Navy.
The recent U.S. midterm elections bring in a new congress that we expect will prove to be a moderating force on reforms such as the government’s insourcing initiative but one that will attempt to address concerns over budget deficits and their impact on the discretionary spending across the government.
We continue to believe that our capabilities in delivering cost effective operational services and IT solutions which improve productivity are well aligned with the leadership objectives to achieve more with less government programs.
During last quarter’s call, we also discussed the U.S. federal government’s IT reform initiative that focused on financial systems and high profile IT programs. I thought it would be useful to take a couple of minutes on this call to provide some color on two of CSC’s mission-critical programs.
CSC’s Army Logistics Modernization Program, LMP, is one of the largest if not the largest ERP implementation in the world with over 21,000 users globally. After the system successfully closed its financial books for the government fiscal year ending in September, this solution was deployed through its final tranche of users stationed at 29 locations across the globe. This massive go-live event successfully completes the LMP deployment which now will transition upon approval to operations and support.
Release 3 of the FAA’s Traffic Flow Management Modernization Program went live on the 21st of August. Since then if you have gone anywhere within the continental United States, both the air traffic controllers and your flight crew have relied on this software release to help ensure your safe and timely flight.
Each of these mission-critical systems is essential to the functioning of its agency and the delivery of the goods and services we expect from government. As such, we strongly believe that the sponsors of mission-critical undertakings will continue to ensure their success, including the prioritization and allocation of scarce resources.
Turning to NHS, we’ve been engaged with NHS in detailed discussions over the past quarter. We are optimistic that an agreed MOU is forthcoming on CSC’s local service provider contract for the North Midland and East of England. This program has been realigned in light of the NHS’s changed agenda and in response to the U.K. government initiative to significantly reduce its overall expenditure.
As previously announced by the NHS, the contract value will be reduced by approximately £500 million and includes scope adjustments. Our revised guidance reflects the expected impact of this realignment.
After successfully completing the Lorenzo Release 1.9 implementation at the four early adopted trust CSC will then move on to the full deployment of this solution. I am pleased to the note that Birmingham Women’s NHS Foundation Trust became the third early adopter of our Lorenzo Release 1.9 solution as they went live on November 1.
Early indications are positive and demonstrate further progress in the maturation of the solution and the go-live process that has resulted from the early adopter program. In summary, we look forward to a positive second half and solid full year results.
I’ll now turn it over to Mike Mancuso for further details of our second quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of fiscal year ‘11 including guidance modifications and the Nordic accounting adjustments reflected in our press release.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I think Mike Laphen’s remarks very clearly articulated the healthy status of our markets, our solid positioning in those markets, and the very favorable outlook for CSC, as this economic recovery gain
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I think Mike Laphen’s remarks very clearly articulated the healthy status of our markets, our solid positioning in those markets, and the very favorable outlook for CSC, as this economic recovery gains momentum.
My mission this morning is to provide you with the necessary insight into our financial results for the quarter, to enhance your understanding of our performance. I’ll start out by saying we feel good about the quarter. We feel good about where we stand at the halfway point of our fiscal year, and we remain optimistic we will achieve the full year targets we have set for ourselves.
I’ll begin with chart number 7; sequentially, we achieved our goal of continuous improvement in each quarter throughout the year. Every important financial metric is better than the previous quarter. Year-over-year comparisons of revenue, operating earnings, margin and EPS require several adjustments to normalize the divestitures, claim settlements, the Nordics adjustment, and a significantly different tax rate.
If you’ll turn now to chart number 8; this chart entitled backlog to revenue is intended to support our revenue forecast by laying out how much in year revenue will come from existing backlog. The message on the chart can be found at the top of the pyramid in that only 2% of our in year revenue is dependent on new business that is not now in backlog.
Chart number 9 displays the new bookings profile over the last six quarters. Our positioning through the first two quarters of this year is quite similar to last year’s pattern, where we achieved over $19 billion in new business for the year. Our identified qualified pipeline that Mike Laphen referred to gives us the confidence that our $18.5 billion plus guidance target is achievable.
Chart number 10 addresses currency. 64% of our cost and revenue is denominated in U.S. dollars and as you can see our second largest currency is the British pound at 11%. Assuming the November 8th spot rate, we do not currency as an issue for us in FY ‘11. Also worthy to note is that the bulk of our cost is denominated and paid for in local currency creating a natural hedge. Our primary risk, such that it is, is translation for reporting purposes.
Chart number 11 displays year-over-year revenue by our three lines of business. NPS has the only negative variance from last year, a result of the slowdown of federal government awards in the first half and the large one-time $65 million claim settlement reflected in the FY ‘10 revenue. BSS would have a more significant increase if adjusted for divestiture.
I also want to point out that the Nordics margin adjustments also included a $36 million revenue reversal. Adjusting both years for the claim settlement, divestiture impact and the Nordic reversal, year-over-year revenue would have increased by $70 million or 2%.
Chart number 12 reflects operating income by line of business. The message on this chart is threefold. NPS despite lower revenue is $22 million better than last year. MSS is dramatically lower, predominantly impacted by the charges taken in our Nordics business to correct misapplication of internal accounting policies, U.S. GAAP and accounting irregularities, and BSS has increased over $10 million on very modest revenue growth.
Chart number 13 presents the year-over-year P&L comparison. There are two important points to be made. If you focus on the other income/expense line, you’ll see income of $35 million this year. Roughly two-third represents the gain on the sale of our MSE business that Mike Laphen mentioned.
The second item is the tax rate which is significantly higher this year. The MSE gain somewhat offsets to Nordics adjustment impact on operating income and normalizing for the tax rate makes for a more meaningful comparison of year-over-year results.
Chart number 14 attempts to further normalize for the year-over-year variations including margin rates, but for the Nordics events, our rate would compare more favorably to last year.
Chart number 15, first half results, first half to first half we are about where we were last year but better positioned this year for second half revenue growth in a recovering economy.
Chart number 16 reflects the balance sheet comparison with the last year. Cash is $250 million higher at quarter end. Liabilities are much lower, thus higher equity and much improved ratios. Not reflected on this chart is the fact that earlier this quarter using our cash we paid down $750 million of our drawn $1.5 billion bank loan.
Turning to chart number 17, it displays our days receivable for the last five quarters. While our trend line is good, we did have enough picking days from last quarter. There are no underlying issues and we expect to meet our reduction target for the year.
Chart number 18 selected cash flow items for the first half versus last year. Cash flow from earnings is unchanged. Operating cash flow has improved, but offset by the increased CapEx which accounts for the variance in free cash flow. This is a timing variance, and we expect CapEx to decline in the second half.
Chart number 19 is our quarterly EPS guidance. We have increased our EPS guidance for the full year by $0.05. Our third and fourth quarter range is not dramatically different from prior guidance. We expect our tax rate for the full year to decrease from our prior guidance of 32% to below 30%. For those of you that are looking for a specific number, I would use 29% for now.
Chart number 20, reflects our updated guidance. Our strong pipeline gives us the confidence to raise our bookings number to $18.5 billion plus from the $18 billion plus prior. We still believe revenue will grow appreciably in the second half of the year, but because of the delays in the federal procurement awards the MSE divestiture and an anticipated modest reduction in NHS revenue, we have lowered the top end of our range from $17.2 to $17 billion and the lower end from $16.8 billion to $16.5 billion.
The Nordics issue and its lingering cost structure issues caused us to adjust the margin range downward for now. You’ll recall we expected 25 to 50 basis points of improvements for the year, and 9.25% was our top end. We have adjusted it to 9%.
We have increased our EPS in the strength of our tax rate reduction and remain confident that free cash flow will exceed 90% of net income. Reflecting on how you should think about the Nordics in adjustments, try to keep in mind that a business is geographically dispersed as ours, will present controlled challenges from time to time, and we are in 94 countries. The good news is we found it, fixed it, and put it behind us.
So, again to summarize how we feel, we are still bullish on the year. We feel good about our second half revenue growth. The accounting issues at Nordics are non-recurring and should be thought of as a bump in the road to an otherwise positive first half.
That being said, I’ll turn it back to Bryan to kick-off the Q&A.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, and that’s not the saying we’re sitting back on our heels now and have accepted this bump in the road, so to speak, as it free to come. We’re striving to get back obviously to where we were, not ready to predict that at this point in time, bu
componenttext: Right, and that’s not the saying we’re sitting back on our heels now and have accepted this bump in the road, so to speak, as it free to come. We’re striving to get back obviously to where we were, not ready to predict that at this point in time, but there’s plenty of runway left so we should think of it to now as leaving the guidance for the moment, but that effort is still underway.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another point to just touch on BSS, I mean, the segment growth looked pretty strong to us, clearly you’re in positive territory now in constant currency basis, couple of percent of growth now. I think does illustrate some of your strength that you’ve
componenttext: Another point to just touch on BSS, I mean, the segment growth looked pretty strong to us, clearly you’re in positive territory now in constant currency basis, couple of percent of growth now. I think does illustrate some of your strength that you’ve had in some of the Cloud areas, some of new growth areas Cloud and cyber, potentially desktop virtualization looking pretty good. What type of growth would you say is sort of more normalized for that segment, at least going into next year over the course of the next 12 months?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we’re looking for at least similar growth in the second half. I think being a bit optimistic, I would say, I think upper single-digit next year is quite doable from what we see at this point.
componenttext: Well, I think we’re looking for at least similar growth in the second half. I think being a bit optimistic, I would say, I think upper single-digit next year is quite doable from what we see at this point.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of just contracts you’re coming up to, I mean, your competition, you seem to be obviously be winning certain amount of these contracts is it pricing related, is it just your expertise. Can you help us understand that?
componenttext: And then in terms of just contracts you’re coming up to, I mean, your competition, you seem to be obviously be winning certain amount of these contracts is it pricing related, is it just your expertise. Can you help us understand that?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, I think we’re doing a very good job investing in new solutions and new technology development, clearly, in cloud and cyber are great examples of that and as you said, the virtual desktop as well. So, I think we’re getting out front and
componenttext: Well, frankly, I think we’re doing a very good job investing in new solutions and new technology development, clearly, in cloud and cyber are great examples of that and as you said, the virtual desktop as well. So, I think we’re getting out front and leading the market in some key technology areas and I would say that’s complemented by our strategic thrust to align ourselves along an industry front, so coupling industry capability now with their technology that we’ve always had I think is paying dividends right now.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: Good morning. Thank you. Mike Mancuso, there were a lot of moving pieces I think that both impacted the quarter and the guidance. I was wondering could you give us the breakdown I think for the Nordics in terms of its impact on margins. But could you take the major items including NHS and help us understand both the revenue impact down the margin impact as we go forward for each of these different items?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I understand your question, David, it’s the margin wrapped around the revenue guidance change, is that the root of your question?
componenttext: If I understand your question, David, it’s the margin wrapped around the revenue guidance change, is that the root of your question?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really just for the different thing, you had a divesture that, you had re-scoping of the NHS and then we had the Nordic issue. Those three things seem to be impacting the outlook. I was wondering if you could just help us understand both the revenue and m
componenttext: Really just for the different thing, you had a divesture that, you had re-scoping of the NHS and then we had the Nordic issue. Those three things seem to be impacting the outlook. I was wondering if you could just help us understand both the revenue and margin impact in each of those three different things.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about it. First of all, I am not going to get into the revenue impact on the NHS but I would tell you that the margin rate itself is not affected in terms of its rate. The revenue line will be smaller to some degree not much but t
componenttext:
I think you should think about it. First of all, I am not going to get into the revenue impact on the NHS but I would tell you that the margin rate itself is not affected in terms of its rate. The revenue line will be smaller to some degree not much but there is not a change in the margin, it’s just the contribution of the NHS in the year for margin will be less than it was anticipated in the prior guidance.
As far as the other impacts, the Nordics was $40 million plus, 40-ish was the problem there. Other than that, margins are intact. We don’t have any other issues, underperforming businesses, etc., etc., The Nordics region itself is soft frankly. It’s lagging the European recovery. We have what we refer to as redundancy issues there. We have excess staff to the amount of business that they have been able to capture for the moment. That’s creating a going forward drain on our margins. We have to deal with that. As you know the European government’s rule are rather expensive and if we shed the workforce it comes with a price tag. If we shed this workforce and then there is an uptick in revenue, we have to bring them back. So it’s a balancing act. So that’s about the best color I can give you on the numbers.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to that David is the divestiture we made was at the very end of the quarter. So it really doesn’t impact the second quarter numbers. It obviously impacts the second half numbers and you can think it in terms of that being at t
componenttext: The only thing I would add to that David is the divestiture we made was at the very end of the quarter. So it really doesn’t impact the second quarter numbers. It obviously impacts the second half numbers and you can think it in terms of that being at the average NPS margin level, so again from a margin perspective, pretty neutral.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how much of revenue was that Mike, the divestiture on a run rate on an annualized basis?
componenttext: And how much of revenue was that Mike, the divestiture on a run rate on an annualized basis?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s roughly $100 million on an annual basis, so think of that a bit. The second half will be perturbated [ph] by about $50 million of the absence of the MSE business.
componenttext: It’s roughly $100 million on an annual basis, so think of that a bit. The second half will be perturbated [ph] by about $50 million of the absence of the MSE business.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the margins themselves on a year-over-year basis, I was looking at your chart which is very helpful, just kind of backing out all the noise in the quarter. It looks like you are up roughly 6 basis points year-over-year, is this just an unusual
componenttext: In terms of the margins themselves on a year-over-year basis, I was looking at your chart which is very helpful, just kind of backing out all the noise in the quarter. It looks like you are up roughly 6 basis points year-over-year, is this just an unusual quarter because obviously the year-over-year margin expansion have been much more robust leading up to this quarter, but there is just so much noise going on that it really distorts the numbers or is the pace of expansion slowing, if you will, as we go forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, one part of it is that it’s a summer month, so it’s a lower utilization of a lot of our stats. So you will see higher utilization in the third and fourth quarter which drives our profitability and also the growth of the new business which we wi
componenttext: David, one part of it is that it’s a summer month, so it’s a lower utilization of a lot of our stats. So you will see higher utilization in the third and fourth quarter which drives our profitability and also the growth of the new business which we will leverage more broadly, which would drive our margin as well. So, I wouldn’t read too much in that second quarter difference.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just one last question on NHS. Is it fair to say that from where you sit right now and the revised guidance that you’ve given that you have reasonably good visibility on the re-scoping, even though the final MOU hasn’t come out yet?
componenttext: Okay, and just one last question on NHS. Is it fair to say that from where you sit right now and the revised guidance that you’ve given that you have reasonably good visibility on the re-scoping, even though the final MOU hasn’t come out yet?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I believe so. I am hoping that we’re days away from a signed MOU versus weeks away. We’ve obviously jointly put a lot of time and effort into this, and as I hopefully will conclude this shortly, I admit face-to-face with the NHS leadership on the prog
componenttext: I believe so. I am hoping that we’re days away from a signed MOU versus weeks away. We’ve obviously jointly put a lot of time and effort into this, and as I hopefully will conclude this shortly, I admit face-to-face with the NHS leadership on the program just recently. I believe both CSC is fully committed to go forward plan and my sense is that, that’s the same for the NHS. So, I think we have pretty good clarity at this point.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, David. Could we take the next question?
componenttext: Okay, thank you, David. Could we take the next question?

componenttext: That will come from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, guys. You showed good management recorded by heading EPS despite the margin headwinds. Can you give us just a better sense of what was in other income, and how should we think about this going forward?
componenttext: Thanks. Good morning, guys. You showed good management recorded by heading EPS despite the margin headwinds. Can you give us just a better sense of what was in other income, and how should we think about this going forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two pieces, Adam in other income, one is, as I said, two-thirds of that $35 million is a gain on the sale of the MSE business, and the other third is predominantly hedging gains on foreign currency. Going forward, it’s hard to predict hedging, don’t s
componenttext: Two pieces, Adam in other income, one is, as I said, two-thirds of that $35 million is a gain on the sale of the MSE business, and the other third is predominantly hedging gains on foreign currency. Going forward, it’s hard to predict hedging, don’t see any other divestiture gains going forward as it relates to other income

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little bit more color on NPS, and what are the conditions right now in the decision making process with the election as a concern over budgets. Now that we’re heading into new fiscal year for the government, what should we expect from the speed of dec
componenttext: A little bit more color on NPS, and what are the conditions right now in the decision making process with the election as a concern over budgets. Now that we’re heading into new fiscal year for the government, what should we expect from the speed of decision making forward do you think?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are going to continue to see some delays in procurements, and I think we’re going to continue to see the escalated level of protest. So, unfortunately, I think that’s here for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, on the positive
componenttext: Well, I think we are going to continue to see some delays in procurements, and I think we’re going to continue to see the escalated level of protest. So, unfortunately, I think that’s here for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, on the positive side, we’ve booked some tremendous business recently and we’ve got some the protest behind us, so we feel that we’ve got a good growth profile going forward. I would think in terms of mid-single-digits for that part of our business at this point in times for both the second half and probably going into next fiscal year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Adam, to add to that, just to remind you, you probably have seen it throughout the quarter, as Mike said, we had significant IDIQ wins in the quarter. They are hard to obviously calculate what the contribution of those will be because you have to win the
componenttext: Adam, to add to that, just to remind you, you probably have seen it throughout the quarter, as Mike said, we had significant IDIQ wins in the quarter. They are hard to obviously calculate what the contribution of those will be because you have to win the task orders, some of which were source for in particular large ones, other ones will compete for; but a very sizable amount of IDIQ awards in the quarter which again though reflecting backlog yet, but still provide comfort in opportunity as we look out beyond this year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

componenttext: Thanks, Adam. Could we have the next question, operator please?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys, thanks for taking my question. I was wondering if we could go back to the backlog to revenue slide, and its look like you are looking at only 2% new business in order to hit your numbers for the year. What kind of backlog to revenue conversion a
componenttext: Hi, guys, thanks for taking my question. I was wondering if we could go back to the backlog to revenue slide, and its look like you are looking at only 2% new business in order to hit your numbers for the year. What kind of backlog to revenue conversion assumptions are in that slide? Is this a normal backlog to revenue conversion assumption or is there anything special going on that we should be aware of?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, it’s the second quarter in a row we’ve used this slide. If I had included the first quarter slide, you’d see that the blue area has grown a few percentage points. The top of the pyramid has shrunk the few percentage points. Our backlog is almos
componenttext: Joe, it’s the second quarter in a row we’ve used this slide. If I had included the first quarter slide, you’d see that the blue area has grown a few percentage points. The top of the pyramid has shrunk the few percentage points. Our backlog is almost unchanged in rounding. It’s still around the $42 billion in the quarter. The IDIQ potential, if you look last quarter, it was $6 billion. We’ve thrown a little plus sign into it at this time. That indicates that the amount of additional IDIQ would work if we weren’t in the second quarter, that would trying to refine, so that we can upgrade this particular number to a more current status. So, longwinded answer, there aren’t anything different, unique or whatever in this particular chart other than the top of the pyramid is shrinking.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. That’s helpful. And then I know I think I heard in your remarks that you actually paid down a little bit more of the debt here post the quarter, but you’re still sitting on a couple of billion dollars of cash. So, if you had any updated thoughts
componenttext: Okay. That’s helpful. And then I know I think I heard in your remarks that you actually paid down a little bit more of the debt here post the quarter, but you’re still sitting on a couple of billion dollars of cash. So, if you had any updated thoughts on balance sheet deployment for shareholder purposes here?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, etcetera. We continue to posture ourselves, as you know, we’re looking at growing by internal investment by acquisition, etc., So, all of those factors or opportunities has
componenttext: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, etcetera. We continue to posture ourselves, as you know, we’re looking at growing by internal investment by acquisition, etc., So, all of those factors or opportunities has been cranked into our thinking. We also have a large revolver that we want to get ourselves out from under in anticipation of which way interest rates are going to go. So, I think you’ll see more from us in this particular area as we rethink our debt profiles and the make-up of our debt etc., and of course as we continue to generate cash flow that will present opportunity for us.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, thank you very much. Operator, the next caller please.
componenttext: Joe, thank you very much. Operator, the next caller please.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ll hear from Joseph Foresi with Janney Montgomery Scott
componenttext: We’ll hear from Joseph Foresi with Janney Montgomery Scott

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, gentlemen. Two quick questions here; first, I know you talked about the IDIQs increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays on some of the government decision making. Are
componenttext: Hi, gentlemen. Two quick questions here; first, I know you talked about the IDIQs increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays on some of the government decision making. Are these mission critical IDIQs? Is that the reason why you have confidence that they are going to come through even though they are getting signed?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a good question, Joe. It’s a tough one to answer to try and clarify it for you. If you look at the year I think you’d see that the second quarter included significantly more IDIQ activity, in general, in U.S. government versus the first quart
componenttext: That’s a good question, Joe. It’s a tough one to answer to try and clarify it for you. If you look at the year I think you’d see that the second quarter included significantly more IDIQ activity, in general, in U.S. government versus the first quarter. There are still a number of key positions in the government that are unfilled. By virtue of the fact they are awarding the IDIQs, that’s good news, yet to follow good news is how quickly they can turn those into specific task orders. That’s where we’re being conservative in the sense that in the second half of the year the government has to move more quickly and more nimble than it have in the first half of the year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe I would add that I think historically we have called out upper single-digit growth in that market, you heard me a few moments ago refer to mid single-digits and I think that reflects our caution around what’s going to happen in the IDIQs and in
componenttext: Yes, Joe I would add that I think historically we have called out upper single-digit growth in that market, you heard me a few moments ago refer to mid single-digits and I think that reflects our caution around what’s going to happen in the IDIQs and in the protest arena. So, we backed off a little bit to reflect what we see out there at this point in time.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the assumption is that IDIQs are increasing, but you’re taking a more conservative approach to the rate at which they get decided on, am I phrasing that correctly?
componenttext: So the assumption is that IDIQs are increasing, but you’re taking a more conservative approach to the rate at which they get decided on, am I phrasing that correctly?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I would say that IDIQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that’s the contract vehicle of choice these days. I don’t see that changing. So, I think we are just going to have to learn to li
componenttext: Yes, I think I would say that IDIQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that’s the contract vehicle of choice these days. I don’t see that changing. So, I think we are just going to have to learn to live with this.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you very much, Joe. Operator.
componenttext: Okay, thank you very much, Joe. Operator.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ll hear from Bryan Keane with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We’ll hear from Bryan Keane with Credit Suisse.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, hi, good morning. Just looking at the revenue guidance, for the second half it looks like growth rate to hit the midpoint of revenue guidance it’s going to be at least 7% growth. So just trying to get some color around how that’s going to look be
componenttext: Yes, hi, good morning. Just looking at the revenue guidance, for the second half it looks like growth rate to hit the midpoint of revenue guidance it’s going to be at least 7% growth. So just trying to get some color around how that’s going to look between quarters, the third quarter and the fourth quarter? Should it be balanced equally? And where does the pop in revenue come from? I know we talked about the NAP business, but do we also see in BSS and MSS as well?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I would say in terms of third quarter and fourth quarter it will be more weighted to the fourth quarter than the third quarter. The pops are coming from a number of the opportunities that we have won that are coming in more directly into the revenue
componenttext:
What I would say in terms of third quarter and fourth quarter it will be more weighted to the fourth quarter than the third quarter. The pops are coming from a number of the opportunities that we have won that are coming in more directly into the revenue line, again that brings you back to Zurich, UBS on the commercial side.
On the federal side, I referred earlier to the TSA contract coming through the transition period and now moving into full scale. Our recent award on Social Security is a direct task where that will get started up shortly. So there is a lot of things in the mix that we are expecting to contribute to that growth number that you have referred to.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Zurich and UBS, have they already started to ramp and do they accelerate here in the third and fourth quarters?
componenttext: And Zurich and UBS, have they already started to ramp and do they accelerate here in the third and fourth quarters?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, they accelerate in the third and fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes, they accelerate in the third and fourth quarter.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just going to ask a quick one on operating margins. It looked like the operating margins improved quite a bit and the NPS and BSS businesses. Should we think about those as sustainable levels? I mean, the increase year-over-year was pretty impressiv
componenttext: I was just going to ask a quick one on operating margins. It looked like the operating margins improved quite a bit and the NPS and BSS businesses. Should we think about those as sustainable levels? I mean, the increase year-over-year was pretty impressive?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the BSS we expect to continue to see good margin improvement. The NPS had a very good quarter and I wouldn’t project that at a straight line going out, I’d go back to our normal guidance on NPS.
componenttext: I think on the BSS we expect to continue to see good margin improvement. The NPS had a very good quarter and I wouldn’t project that at a straight line going out, I’d go back to our normal guidance on NPS.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Bryan, thanks a lot. Operator?.
componenttext: Okay, Bryan, thanks a lot. Operator?.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.
componenttext: Next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: To go back to the federal business, as we sort of look at lend up Congress and maybe the post-calendar quarter of next year has the impact of congressional committee changes. Are you basically looking at a lot of spending or spending pent-up demand coming
componenttext: To go back to the federal business, as we sort of look at lend up Congress and maybe the post-calendar quarter of next year has the impact of congressional committee changes. Are you basically looking at a lot of spending or spending pent-up demand coming in, in the early part of the next fiscal year for you, is that how things get pushed out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, what we’re reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is the business that we have recently won that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn’t say so much pent-up, I would say it
componenttext: Well, I would say, what we’re reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is the business that we have recently won that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn’t say so much pent-up, I would say it’s the business that we’ve captured most recently. We’ve done quite well in the marketplace there. Looking past that, I think it would be difficult to project what the new Congress is going to do and how they’re going to square with the administration on federal spending. So I think we have good visibility in the second half of this year going into the first half of next year but I think I have to leave it at that at this point.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up on the accounting issue that hurt MSS. Is there sort of a high confidence level that the accounting irregularity was limited to the Nordics, have you gone through other jurisdictions, geographies, those kind of things?
componenttext: And a follow-up on the accounting issue that hurt MSS. Is there sort of a high confidence level that the accounting irregularity was limited to the Nordics, have you gone through other jurisdictions, geographies, those kind of things?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ashwin, of course we have. We’ve obviously looked at the issues in the Nordics, for example, misapplication of accounting policy etc., etc. We have looked across the corporation to satisfy ourselves that it’s not pervasive etc., but it’s localized.
componenttext: Ashwin, of course we have. We’ve obviously looked at the issues in the Nordics, for example, misapplication of accounting policy etc., etc. We have looked across the corporation to satisfy ourselves that it’s not pervasive etc., but it’s localized. We are confident at this point that it is localized. And we’re really very confident you won’t see that kind of behavior repeat itself, certainly it won’t in the Nordics because the people aren’t there anymore.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Ashwin. Operator?
componenttext: Thanks a lot, Ashwin. Operator?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.
componenttext: Next question will come from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. So I guess it’s been about a year since you outlined new long-term financial guidance, the average organic revenue growth 6% to 8% through fiscal ‘13 I believe and the operating margin of at least 10% by fiscal ‘13 etc.,. So I guess ba
componenttext: Thanks, guys. So I guess it’s been about a year since you outlined new long-term financial guidance, the average organic revenue growth 6% to 8% through fiscal ‘13 I believe and the operating margin of at least 10% by fiscal ‘13 etc.,. So I guess based on how fiscal ‘11 is coming in and what you see in your end markets going forward, are you still comfortable with this forecast and can you give us a sense of what elements of this forecast could potentially be most at risk?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll give you this input, Jason. I think that forecast is still a reasonable expectation of our aspirations and expectations. We’re going through our annual strategic planning process right now where we’re taking a forward look of the next couple of
componenttext: I’ll give you this input, Jason. I think that forecast is still a reasonable expectation of our aspirations and expectations. We’re going through our annual strategic planning process right now where we’re taking a forward look of the next couple of years and if appropriate, we’ll modify them at that point in time. We’ll probably come out to this recent time in the first quarter of next calendar year with some sort of Investors Day event that we would share with you the outcome of our efforts on the strategic plan and projections.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010

Well, I am not going to speak for the Board and how they think philosophically. I think we have a robust business and we will continue to be robust business. So I don’t think we spend a whole lot of time going down that path thinking about that possibility.
In terms of stock buybacks, again that will be part of the consideration as all the capital structure will be as we go through our strategic plan in the December process and go through with the Board review at that point in time.
