headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2011 Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CSC Fiscal Year 2011 Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Bryan Brady, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Well, good morning, everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC's Earnings Call for the second quarter of our fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you've had a good opportunity to review them. W
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Well, good morning, everyone, and a warm welcome to CSC's Earnings Call for the second quarter of our fiscal year 2011. We issued our financial results earlier this morning, so hopefully you've had a good opportunity to review them. With me today are Mike Laphen, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mike Mancuso, our Chief Financial Officer. As usual, the call is being webcast at csc.com and we've also posted slides to our website to accompany our discussion.
Now moving to Slide 2, you'll see a reminder that statements made during this call that are not historical facts may be considered forward-looking statements under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties is contained in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies of these filings are available from the SEC, from our website and from our Investor Relations department.
On Slide 3, you'll see our acknowledgment that CSC's presentation includes certain non-GAAP financial measures. In accordance with SEC rules, a reconciliation of these metrics to GAAP metrics is included in the tables of the earnings release and in the appendix to our slides. Both documents are available for your review at the Investor Relations section of the CSC website.
Finally, I'd like to remind our listeners that CSC assumes no obligation to update the information presented on this conference call, except, of course, as required by law. Now if you'll kindly move to Slide #4, I'm pleased to turn the call over to Mike Laphen.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bryan. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us today, as we discuss our financial results for the second quarter. We ended our last earnings call indicating that we expected our second quarter revenue to be similar to t
componenttext:
Thank you, Bryan. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us today, as we discuss our financial results for the second quarter. We ended our last earnings call indicating that we expected our second quarter revenue to be similar to that of the first quarter and that the majority of this year's growth would occur in the second half. Consistent with that earlier view, we delivered modest sequential revenue growth in our second quarter. However, ongoing market improvements, the resolution of a protest on some key public sector awards and the ramp up of new business initiated in the first half, all reinforce our belief that we will experience meaningful top line growth in our second half. 
On the new business front, bookings strengthened to $4.5 billion for the quarter and $7.7 billion for the first half. Based on this first half performance, as well as current activity, we've increased our full-year bookings estimate by $500 million. Across our Global Commercial businesses, we see definite signs of recovery, pipelines are building constructively, customers are actively engaging in the exploration of new initiatives, and most importantly, buying decisions are being made. Business utilization and billing rates have improved and demand for services has increased.
Our consulting pipelines are robust and totaled 3x trailing 12 months revenue. Win rates remained strong, indicating market acceptance of our vertical and consulting solutions and traction for our BPO and industry-focused value propositions. Accordingly, BSS delivered second quarter year-over-year growth of 6%, net of M&A and in constant currency. We expect this growth to continue, if not accelerate, in the second half. 
Demand for outsourcing services remains positive. MSS revenues increased 2% for the quarter and 2.1% for the half in constant currency and we expect this growth to continue in the second half. The demand for application management services is particularly strong and we projected that this segment of the business will grow at low double-digit rates year-over-year.
The outsourcing pipeline for qualified opportunities scheduled for award by the close of our fiscal year '11 stands at $12 billion, driving our optimism for a strong second half bookings. We are particularly pleased to start off our third quarter by welcoming BF Corporation, the world's largest apparel company as a new CSC client. 
Demand for cloud services continues across our markets, and we achieved a number of significant accomplishments. First, we successfully transitioned over 15,000 users across 36 of the city of Los Angeles's 40 departments to our Google-based cloud platform. 
We also recently announced our win on the state of California program for Microsoft BPOS cloud services. Additionally, we were selected by AMP, one of Australia's leading wealth management companies to implement our cloud based solution for email and collaborative services. This solution is based on the Dblock [ph] technology resulting from our announced alliance with the VCE coalition, a collaboration of Cisco, TMC and VMware.
For our ground breaking implementation of cloud-based other [ph] services to 28,000 Royal Mail Group employees, CSC just received the National Outsourcing Association's award for innovation in outsourcing. These accomplishments evidenced CSC's leadership position in the implementation of cloud services across both the public and private sectors. 
Within our Cyber business, we won several new contracts having a combined TCV of $50 million. We're continuing to see a growing pipeline of Cyber opportunities across both the public and commercial sectors. This strengthened our portfolio of Cyber IP and to expand into some new market segments within the world of Cyber. We recently completed the strategic acquisition of a small, but important Cyber company, VRL. This transaction has already generated considerable positive discussion within the community.
Our Federal Sector business, MPS, delivered strong second quarter bookings, totaling approximately $2.9 billion, which provides a good foundation for second half growth. These second quarter new business bookings include over $600 million of new TCV across the federal healthcare market space, with wins at the Health and Human Services centers for Medicare and Medicaid services, the National Institutes of Health, the Department of Defense Health Affairs and the Department of Labor Office of Workers compensation programs.
Other important second quarter NPS wins totaling over $1 billion in TCV include delivery orders for the Department of State Visa support services in Mexico, the U.S. Army flight school 21, IT infrastructure services for a major intelligence agency and an important win at the Social Security Agency for information technology support. In addition to the solid first half bookings result, the MPS pipeline remains strong with $18 billion of qualified opportunities that are scheduled to be awarded over the next 12 months, $9 billion of which is scheduled for award by the end of CSC's fiscal year.
Our constructive view of MPS growth in the second half is also based on a resolution of two important protests, including the TSA ITIP program. We're finally starting on this program in September and its now in its late stages of the planned 90 day transition phase. I would now like to provide some updates to several of the investor topics of interest we discussed during our last earnings call.
With respect to our business with the U.S. federal government, we divested at the end of the quarter a subsidiary of MPS, Mission Solutions Engineering Inc. Resolving government concerns of conflicts of interest with other currency CSC programs at the Missile Defense Agency and the U.S. Navy. The recent U.S. midterm elections bring in a new Congress that we expect will prove to be a moderating force on reforms such as the government's insourcing initiatives, but one that will attempt to address concerns over budget deficits and their impact on the discretionary spending across the government. We continue to believe that our capabilities in delivering cost-effective, operational services and IT solutions which improved productivity are well aligned with the leadership objectives to achieved more request in government programs.
During last quarter's call, we also discussed the U.S. federal government's IT reform initiatives that focused on financial systems and high-profile IT programs. I thought it would be useful to take a couple of minutes on this call to provide some color on two of CSC's mission critical programs. CSC's Army Logistics Modernization Program, LMP, is one of the largest, if not the largest, ERP implementation in the world, with over 21,000 users globally. After the system successfully closed its financial books for the government fiscal year ending in September, this solution was deployed to its final tranche of users stationed at 29 locations across the globe. This massive go live event successfully completes the LMP deployments which will now transition upon approval to operations and support. 
Release Three of the FAA's traffic flow management modernization program went live on the 21st of August. Since then, if you have flown anywhere within the continental United States, both the air traffic controllers and your flight crew have relied on this software release to help ensure your safe and timely flight. Each of these mission critical systems is essential to the function of its agency and to the delivery of the goods and services we expect from government. As such, we strongly believe that sponsors of mission-critical undertakings will continue to ensure their success, including the prioritization and allocation of scarce resources.
Turning to NHS. We've been engaged with NHS in detailed discussions over the past quarter. We are optimistic that an agreed MOU is forthcoming on CSC's local service provider contract for the north, midlands, and east of England. This program is built and end up [ph] being realigned in light of the NHS changed agenda and in response to the U.K. government's initiative to significantly reduce its overall expenditure. As previously announced by the NHS, the contract value will be reduced by approximately 500 million pounds and includes scope adjustments. Our revised guidance reflects the expected impact of this realignment.
After successfully completing the Lorenzo Release 1.9 implementation at the four early adopted trusts, CSC will then move on to the full deployment of this solution. To this end, I am pleased to note that Birmingham Women's NHS Foundation Trust became the third early adopter of our Lorenzo Release 1.9 solution as they went live on November 1. Early indications are positive and demonstrate further progress in the maturation of this solution and the go live process that has resulted from the early adoptive program.
In summary, we look forward to a positive second half and solid full year results. I'll now turn it over to Mike Mancuso for further details of our second quarter results and our outlook for the remainder of fiscal year '11, including guidance modifications and the Nordic accounting adjustments reflected in our press release.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I think Mike Laphin’s remarks very clearly articulated the healthy status of our markets, our solid positioning in those markets, and the very favorable outlook for CSC as this economic recovery gain
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I think Mike Laphin’s remarks very clearly articulated the healthy status of our markets, our solid positioning in those markets, and the very favorable outlook for CSC as this economic recovery gains momentum. My mission this morning is to provide you with the necessary insight into our financial results for the quarter to enhance your understanding of our performance. I will start out by saying we feel good about the quarter, we feel good about where we stand at the halfway point of our fiscal year, and we remain optimistic we will achieve the full year targets we have set for ourselves. I'll begin with Chart 7.
Sequentially, we achieved our goal of continuous improvement in each quarter throughout the year. Every important financial metric is better than the previous quarter. Year-over-year comparisons of revenue, operating earnings, margin and EPS requires several adjustments to normalize the divestitures, claim settlements, the Nordics adjustment and a significantly different tax rate. 
If you'll turn now to Chart 8. This chart entailed backlogs to revenue is intended to support our revenue forecast by laying out how much in-year revenue will come from existing backlog. The message on the chart can be found at the top of the pyramid in that only 2% of our in-year revenue is dependent on new business that is not now in backlog.
Chart 9 displays the new bookings profile over the last six quarters. Our positioning for the first two quarters of this year is quite similar to last year's pattern, where we achieved over $19 billion in new business for the year. Our identified qualified pipeline that Mike Laphen referred to gives us the confidence that our $18.5 billion-plus guidance target is achievable.
Chart #10 addresses currency. 64% of our cost and revenue is denominated in U.S. dollars and as you can see, our second largest currency is the British pound at 11%. Assuming the November 8 spot rate, we do not see currency as an issue for us in FY '11. Also worthy to note is that the bulk of our costs is denominated in paid for in local currency, creating a natural hedge. Our primary risk, such that it is, is translation for reporting purposes.
Chart 11 displays year-over-year revenue by our three lines of business. NPS has the only negative variance from last year, a result of the slowdown of federal government awards in the first half and the large one-time $65 million claim settlement reflected in the FY '10 revenue. BSS would have a more significant increase if adjusted for a divestiture. I also want to point out that the Nordics margin adjustments also included a $36 million revenue reversal. Adjusting both years for the claims settlement, divestiture impact and the Nordic reversal, year-over-year revenue would have increased by $70 million or 2%.
Slide 12 reflects operating income by line of business. The message on this chart is threefold. NPS, despite lower revenue is $22 million better than last year. MSS is dramatically lower, predominately impacted by the charges taken in our Nordics business to correct misapplication of internal accounting policies, U.S. GAAP and accounting irregularities. And BSS has increased over $10 million on very modest revenue growth.
Chart 13 presents the year-over-year P&L comparison. There are two important points to be made. If you focus on the other income expense line, you will see income of $35 million this year, roughly 2/3 represents the gain on the sale of our MS e-business that Mike Laphen mentioned. The second item is the tax rate which is significantly higher this year. The MSE gain somewhat offsets the Nordics adjustments impact on operating income and normalizing for the tax rate makes for a more meaningful comparison of year-over-year results.
Chart 14 intends to further normalize for the year-over-year variations, including margin rates. But for the Nordics events, our rate would compare more favorably to last year. 
Chart 15 first half results. First half to first half, we are about where we were last year, but better positioned this year for second half revenue growth in a recovering economy.
Chart 16 reflects the balance sheet comparisons to last year. Cash is $250 million higher at quarter end, liabilities are much lower, less higher equity and much improved ratios. Not reflected on this chart is the fact that earlier this quarter, using our cash, we paid down $750 million of our drawn $1.5 billion bank line.
Turning to Chart 17, it displays our days receivable for the last five quarters, while our trend line is good, we did have an uptick in days from last quarter. There are no underlying issues and we expect to meet our reduction target for the year.
Chart 18, selected cash flow items for the first half versus last year. Cash flow from earnings is unchanged. Operating cash flow has improved, but offset by the increased CapEx, which accounts for the variance in free cash flow. This is a timing variance and we expect CapEx to decline in the second half.
Chart 19 is our quarterly EPS guidance. We have increased our EPS guidance for the full year by $0.05. Our third and fourth quarter range is not dramatically different from prior guidance. We expect our tax rate for the full year to decrease from our prior guidance of 32% to below 30%. And for those of you that are looking for a specific number, I would use 29% for now.
Chart 20 reflects our updated guidance. Our strong pipeline gives us the confidence to raise our bookings number to $18.5 billion plus from the $18 billion-plus prior. We still believe revenue will grow appreciably in the second half of the year, but because of the delays in the federal procurement awards, the MSE divestiture and an anticipated modest reduction in NHS revenue, we have lowered the top-end of our range from $17.2 billion to $17 billion and the lower end from $16.8 billion to $16.5 billion. The Nordics issue and its lingering cost structure issues cost us to adjust the margin range downward for now. You'll recall we expected 25 to 50 basis points of improvement for the year, and 9.25% was our top end. We have adjusted it to 9%.
We have increased our EPS and the strength of our tax rate reduction and remain confident that free cash flow will exceed 90% of net income. Reflecting on how you should think about the Nordics adjustment, try to keep in mind that the business is geographically dispersed desires will present controlled challenges from time to time, and we are in 94 countries. The good news is, we found it, we fixed it and put it behind us. 
So again, to summarize how we feel, we are still bullish on the year. We feel good about our second half revenue growth. The accounting issues in the Nordics are nonrecurring, and should be thought of as a bump in the road for an otherwise positive first half. That being said, I'll turn it now back to Bryan to kick off the Q&A.

componenttext: Frankly, I think we're doing a very good job investing in new solutions and new technology development. Clearly, in cloud, and Cyber, a great examples of that and as you said, the virtual desktop as well. So I think we're getting out front and leading the market in some key technology areas and I would say that's complemented by our strategic thrust to align ourselves along an industry front. So coupling industry capability now with that technology that we've always had I think is paying dividends right now.

componenttext: Well, really, just for the different things, you had a divestiture, you had rescoping at the NHS and then we had the Nordics issue. Those three things seemed to be impacting the outlook and I was wondering if you could just help us understand both the revenue and margin impact of each of those three different, each of those three different things?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you should think about it. First of all, I'm not going to get into the revenue impact on the NHS, but I would tell you that the margin rate itself is not affected in terms of its rate. The revenue line will be smaller to some degree, not muc
componenttext: Well, I think you should think about it. First of all, I'm not going to get into the revenue impact on the NHS, but I would tell you that the margin rate itself is not affected in terms of its rate. The revenue line will be smaller to some degree, not much, but some. But the margin, there's not a change in the margin, it's just the contribution and the NHS in the year for margin will be less than it was and less anticipated in the prior guidance. As far as the other impacts, the Nordics was $40 plus million, fortyish was the problem there. Other than that, margins are intact. We don't have any other issues, underperforming business, et cetera. The Nordics Region itself is soft, frankly. It's lagging the European recovery. We have what we refer to as redundancy issues there. We have excess staff to the amount of business that they've been able to capture for the moment. That's creating a going forward drain on our margins. We have to deal with that. As you know, the European federal [ph] rules are rather expensive than if we shed the workforce. It comes with the price tag. If we shed this workforce, and then there's an uptick in revenue, we have to bring them back. So it's a balancing act. So that's about the best color I can give you on the numbers.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to that, David, is the divestiture we made was at the very end of the quarter. So it really doesn't impact a certain quarter numbers. It obviously impacts the second half numbers and you can think of it in terms of that being at
componenttext: The only thing I would add to that, David, is the divestiture we made was at the very end of the quarter. So it really doesn't impact a certain quarter numbers. It obviously impacts the second half numbers and you can think of it in terms of that being at the average MPS margin level. So again, from a margin perspective, pretty neutral.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how much of revenue is that, Mike, the divestiture on a run rate and annualized basis?
componenttext: And how much of revenue is that, Mike, the divestiture on a run rate and annualized basis?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's roughly $100 million on an annual basis, so think about a bit. The second half will be prorated by about $50 million of the absence of the MSC business.
componenttext: It's roughly $100 million on an annual basis, so think about a bit. The second half will be prorated by about $50 million of the absence of the MSC business.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the margins themselves on a year-over-year basis, I was looking at your chart which is very helpful, just kind of backing out all the noise in the quarter, it looks like you're up roughly six basis points year-over-year. Is this just an un
componenttext: And in terms of the margins themselves on a year-over-year basis, I was looking at your chart which is very helpful, just kind of backing out all the noise in the quarter, it looks like you're up roughly six basis points year-over-year. Is this just an unusual quarter which -- because obviously, the year-over-year margin expansion have been much more robust leading up to this quarter, was is just so must noise going on there, really distorts the numbers or is the pace of expansion slowing, if you will, as we go forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's David, one part of it is the summer months, so it's a lower utilization of lot of our staff. So you will see a higher utilization in the third and fourth quarter, which drives our profitability and also the growth of the new business which we w
componenttext: Well, it's David, one part of it is the summer months, so it's a lower utilization of lot of our staff. So you will see a higher utilization in the third and fourth quarter, which drives our profitability and also the growth of the new business which we will leverage more broadly, which would drive our margin as well. So I wouldn't read too much into that in the second quarter difference.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just one last question on NHS, is it fair to say that from where you sit right now and the revised guidance that you've given that you have reasonably good visibility on the rescoping even though the final MOU hasn't come out yet?
componenttext: And just one last question on NHS, is it fair to say that from where you sit right now and the revised guidance that you've given that you have reasonably good visibility on the rescoping even though the final MOU hasn't come out yet?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I believe so. I'm hoping that we're days away from a signed MOU versus weeks away. We've obviously jointly put a lot of time and effort into this and as I said, hopefully we'll conclude this shortly. I've met face-to-face with the NHS leadership on t
componenttext: Yes. I believe so. I'm hoping that we're days away from a signed MOU versus weeks away. We've obviously jointly put a lot of time and effort into this and as I said, hopefully we'll conclude this shortly. I've met face-to-face with the NHS leadership on the program just recently and I believe both CSC is fully committed to go forward planning and my sense is that, that's the same for the NHS. So yes, I think, we have pretty good clarity at this point.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And it will come from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And it will come from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: You showed good managing of the quarter by hitting EPS despite the margin headwinds. Can you give us just a better sense of what was in other income and how should we think about this going forward?
componenttext: You showed good managing of the quarter by hitting EPS despite the margin headwinds. Can you give us just a better sense of what was in other income and how should we think about this going forward?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's like two pieces, Adam, in other income. One is, as I said, 2/3 of that $35 million is a gain on the sale of the MSC business and the other third is predominantly hedging gains on foreign currency. And going forward, it's hard to predict hedging. W
componenttext: There's like two pieces, Adam, in other income. One is, as I said, 2/3 of that $35 million is a gain on the sale of the MSC business and the other third is predominantly hedging gains on foreign currency. And going forward, it's hard to predict hedging. We don't see any other divestiture gains going forward as it relates to other income.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little bit more color on NPS and what's causing -- what are the conditions right now in the decision-making process with the election as a concern over budgets and now that we're heading into a new fiscal year for the government, what should we expect f
componenttext: A little bit more color on NPS and what's causing -- what are the conditions right now in the decision-making process with the election as a concern over budgets and now that we're heading into a new fiscal year for the government, what should we expect from the speed of decision-making going forward, do you think?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll continue to see some delays in procurements. I think we're going to continue to see the escalated level of protests, so unfortunately, I think that's for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, on the positive side, we've booked som
componenttext: Well, I think we'll continue to see some delays in procurements. I think we're going to continue to see the escalated level of protests, so unfortunately, I think that's for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, on the positive side, we've booked some tremendous business recently and we've got some of the protests behind us. So we feel that we've got a good growth profile going forward. I would think in terms of mid-single digits, with that part of our business at this point in time, were for both the second half and probably going into next fiscal year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Adam, to add to that, just to remind you, you've probably seen it throughout the quarter, we as Mike said, we have significant ID/IQ wins in the quarter. They are hard to obviously calculate what the contribution of those will be because you have to win t
componenttext: Adam, to add to that, just to remind you, you've probably seen it throughout the quarter, we as Mike said, we have significant ID/IQ wins in the quarter. They are hard to obviously calculate what the contribution of those will be because you have to win the test quarters, some of which were sold source for -- in particular large ones, other ones we’ll compete for. But a very sizable amount of IDIQ awards in the quarter which, again, don't reflect in backlog yet, but still provide comfort and opportunity as we look out beyond this year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: That will come from Joseph Vafi with Jefferies & Co.
componenttext: That will come from Joseph Vafi with Jefferies & Co.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could go back to the backlog to revenue slide and it looks like you're looking at only 2% new business in order to hit your numbers for the year. What kind of backlog to revenue conversion assumptions are in that slide? Is this a nor
componenttext: I was wondering if we could go back to the backlog to revenue slide and it looks like you're looking at only 2% new business in order to hit your numbers for the year. What kind of backlog to revenue conversion assumptions are in that slide? Is this a normal backlog to revenue conversion assumption or is there anything special going on that we should be aware of?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, it's the second quarter in a row we've used this slide. If I had included the first quarter slide, you'd see that the blue area has grown a few percentage points. The top of the pyramid has shrunk a percentage points. Backlog is almost unchanged in r
componenttext: Joe, it's the second quarter in a row we've used this slide. If I had included the first quarter slide, you'd see that the blue area has grown a few percentage points. The top of the pyramid has shrunk a percentage points. Backlog is almost unchanged in rounding. It's still around the $42 billion in the quarter. The ID/IQ potential, if you look last quarter, it was $6 billion. We've thrown a little plus sign into it this time. That's to indicate that the amount of additional ID/IQ would work that we won in the second quarter, that we're trying to refine so that we can upgrade this particular number to a more current status. So a long-winded answer, there aren't anything different, unique or whatever in this particular chart other than the top of the pyramid is shrinking.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know I think I heard in your remarks that you actually paid down a little bit more to debt here post the quarter but you're still sitting on a couple of billion dollars of cash. I was wondering if had any updated thoughts on balance sheet deployment for
componenttext: I know I think I heard in your remarks that you actually paid down a little bit more to debt here post the quarter but you're still sitting on a couple of billion dollars of cash. I was wondering if had any updated thoughts on balance sheet deployment for shareholder purposes here?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, et cetera. We continue to posture ourselves. As you know, we are looking at growing by internal investments, by acquisition, et cetera. So all of those factors or opportuniti
componenttext: We have ongoing thoughts about how our balance sheet and return to shareholders, et cetera. We continue to posture ourselves. As you know, we are looking at growing by internal investments, by acquisition, et cetera. So all of those factors or opportunities is being cranked into our thinking. We also have a large revolver that we want to get out ourselves out from under in anticipation of which way interests rates are going to go. So I think you'll see more from us in this particular area as we rethink our debt profiles and the makeup of our debt, et cetera. And of course, as we continue to generate cash flow, that will present opportunity for us.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll hear from Joseph Foresi with Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: We'll hear from Joseph Foresi with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I know you talked about the ID/IQ's increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays in some of the government decision-making? Are these mission critical ID/IQ's? Is tha
componenttext: First, I know you talked about the ID/IQ's increasing in the back half of the year. Can you just help us reconcile that with your comments about there being maybe delays in some of the government decision-making? Are these mission critical ID/IQ's? Is that the reason why you have confidence that they're going to come through even though they're getting side?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: There has been, if you look at the year, I think you'd see that the second quarter included significantly more ID/IQ activity in general in the U.S. government versus the first quarter. There are still a number of key positions in the government that are
componenttext: There has been, if you look at the year, I think you'd see that the second quarter included significantly more ID/IQ activity in general in the U.S. government versus the first quarter. There are still a number of key positions in the government that are unfilled. By virtue of the fact they're awarding the ID/IQs, that's good news. The yet to follow good news is how quickly they can turn those into specific task orders and that's where we're being conservative in the sense that the government has to move -- in the second half of the year, the government has to move more quickly and more nimble than they had in the first half of the year.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I would just add that I think historically, we have called out upper single digit growth in that market. You've heard me a few moments ago referred to mid-single digits and I think that reflects our caution around what's going to happen in the ID/IQs
componenttext: Joe, I would just add that I think historically, we have called out upper single digit growth in that market. You've heard me a few moments ago referred to mid-single digits and I think that reflects our caution around what's going to happen in the ID/IQs and in the protest arena. So we've backed off a little bit to reflect what we see out there at this point in time.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the assumption is, that ID/IQs are increasing, but you're taking a more conservative approach to the rate of which they get decided on. Am I appraising that correctly?
componenttext: So the assumption is, that ID/IQs are increasing, but you're taking a more conservative approach to the rate of which they get decided on. Am I appraising that correctly?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, I think that's fair and I would say that ID/IQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that's a contract vehicle of choice these days. I don't see that changing so I think we're just going to ha
componenttext: I think, yes, I think that's fair and I would say that ID/IQs are going to become a bigger and bigger portion of our federal contract base. I mean, that's a contract vehicle of choice these days. I don't see that changing so I think we're just going to have to learn a way with this.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll hear from Bryan Keane with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll hear from Bryan Keane with Credit Suisse.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the revenue guidance. For the second half, it looks like the growth rate will be -- to hit the midpoint of the revenue guidance it's going to be at least 7% growth. So just trying to get some color around how that's going to look between q
componenttext: Just looking at the revenue guidance. For the second half, it looks like the growth rate will be -- to hit the midpoint of the revenue guidance it's going to be at least 7% growth. So just trying to get some color around how that's going to look between quarters, the third quarter and the fourth quarter. Should it be balanced equally? And where does the pop in revenue come from? I know we talked about the NEP business, but do we also see in BSS and MSS as well?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say in terms of the third quarter and fourth quarter, it will be more weighted to the fourth quarter than the third quarter. The pops are coming from a number of the opportunities that we have won that are coming in more directly into the re
componenttext: Well, I would say in terms of the third quarter and fourth quarter, it will be more weighted to the fourth quarter than the third quarter. The pops are coming from a number of the opportunities that we have won that are coming in more directly into the revenue line. Again, that brings you back to Zürich, UBS on the commercial side and on the federal side, I referred earlier to the TSA contract coming through the transition period and now moving into the full scale. Our recent award on Social Security is a direct task order that will get started up shortly. So there's a lot of things in the midst there that we're expecting to contribute to that growth number that you've referred to.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Zürich and UBS, have they already started to ramp and do they accelerate here in the third and fourth quarters?
componenttext: And Zürich and UBS, have they already started to ramp and do they accelerate here in the third and fourth quarters?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, they accelerate in the third and fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes, they accelerate in the third and fourth quarter.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: On operating margins, it look like the operating margins improved quite a bit in the NPS and BSS businesses. Should we think about those as sustainable levels. I mean the increase year-over-year was pretty impressive.
componenttext: On operating margins, it look like the operating margins improved quite a bit in the NPS and BSS businesses. Should we think about those as sustainable levels. I mean the increase year-over-year was pretty impressive.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the BSS, we expect to continue to see good margin improvement. The MPS had a very good quarter and I wouldn't project that at a straight line going out. I would go back to our normal guidance on MPS.
componenttext: I think on the BSS, we expect to continue to see good margin improvement. The MPS had a very good quarter and I wouldn't project that at a straight line going out. I would go back to our normal guidance on MPS.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.
componenttext: Next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citi.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you go back to the federal business, as we start to look at lame duck Congress and maybe the first calendar quarter of next year has the impact of Congressional committee changes, are you basically looking at a lot of spending or spending pent-up deman
componenttext: If you go back to the federal business, as we start to look at lame duck Congress and maybe the first calendar quarter of next year has the impact of Congressional committee changes, are you basically looking at a lot of spending or spending pent-up demand coming in, in the early part of the next fiscal year for you? Is that how things get pushed out?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say what we're reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is the business that we have recently won and that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn't say so much pent-up, I would say it's
componenttext: Well, I would say what we're reflecting right now in the second half and into at least the first half of next year is the business that we have recently won and that will contribute to the revenue line. So I wouldn't say so much pent-up, I would say it's the business that we've captured most recently. We've done quite well in the marketplace there. Looking past of that, I think it would be difficult to project what the new Congress is going to do and how they're going to square with the administration on federal spending. So I think we have good visibility in the second half of this year going into the first half of next year, but I think I'll have to revisit that at this point.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up on the accounting issue, it hurt MSS. Is there sort of a high confidence level that the accounting irregularity will sort of limit to the Nordics? Have you gone through other jurisdictions, geographies, those kinds of things?
componenttext: And a follow-up on the accounting issue, it hurt MSS. Is there sort of a high confidence level that the accounting irregularity will sort of limit to the Nordics? Have you gone through other jurisdictions, geographies, those kinds of things?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ashwin, of course, we have. We've obviously looked at the issues in the Nordics. For example, misapplication of accounting policy, et cetera. We've looked across the corporations to satisfy ourselves, that it's not pervasive, et cetera, but it's localized
componenttext: Ashwin, of course, we have. We've obviously looked at the issues in the Nordics. For example, misapplication of accounting policy, et cetera. We've looked across the corporations to satisfy ourselves, that it's not pervasive, et cetera, but it's localized. We are confident at this point that it is localized. And don't think -- and they are very confident. You don’t see that kind of behavior repeat itself. Certainly, it won't in the Nordics because the people aren't there anymore.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.
componenttext: Next question will come from Jason Kupferberg with UBS.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess it's been about a year since you outlined new long term financial guidance, the average organic revenue growth 6% to 8% through fiscal '13, I believe, and the operating margin at least 10% by fiscal '13, et cetera. So I guess based on how fisca
componenttext: So I guess it's been about a year since you outlined new long term financial guidance, the average organic revenue growth 6% to 8% through fiscal '13, I believe, and the operating margin at least 10% by fiscal '13, et cetera. So I guess based on how fiscal '11 is coming in and what you see in your end markets going forward, are you still comfortable with this forecast and can you give us a sense of what elements of this forecast could potentially be most at risk?

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd give you this input, Jason. I think that forecast is still a reasonable expectation of our aspirations and expectations. We're going through our annual strategic plan process right now where we're taking a forward look of the next couple of year
componenttext: Well, I'd give you this input, Jason. I think that forecast is still a reasonable expectation of our aspirations and expectations. We're going through our annual strategic plan process right now where we're taking a forward look of the next couple of years and if appropriate, we'll modify them at that point in time. We'll probably come out to this rate sometime in the first quarter of next calendar year with some sort of investors day event that we would share with you the outcome of our efforts on the strategic plan and projections.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up from an earlier question regarding the balance sheet, I mean, obviously, there's been a lot of chatter in the marketplace around the potential for CSC to lever up and be an LBO candidate. Mike, maybe just in your position as Chairman,
componenttext: And just a follow-up from an earlier question regarding the balance sheet, I mean, obviously, there's been a lot of chatter in the marketplace around the potential for CSC to lever up and be an LBO candidate. Mike, maybe just in your position as Chairman, can you give us any sense of how the board thinks philosophically about that potential and then also any specific thoughts around share buyback.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to speak for the board and how they think philosophically. I think we have a robust business and we will continue to be robust business. So I don't think we spend a whole lot of time going down that path, thinking about that possibility. I
componenttext: Well, I'm going to speak for the board and how they think philosophically. I think we have a robust business and we will continue to be robust business. So I don't think we spend a whole lot of time going down that path, thinking about that possibility. In terms of stock buybacks, again, that will be part of the consideration as all of the capital structure will be as we go through our strategic plan in the December process and go through with the board review at that point in time.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question will come from Michael Blasse with Bouyant.
componenttext: And our final question will come from Michael Blasse with Bouyant.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: You certainly will, Michael. It will be filed very early afternoon, if it's not there by the time this call ends.
componenttext: You certainly will, Michael. It will be filed very early afternoon, if it's not there by the time this call ends.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the most part, they were not POC contracts, it was -- I don't want to get into a lot of the details, it was capitalizing expense items and things of that ilk. We have internal accounting policies on transition costs and things like that where they're
componenttext: For the most part, they were not POC contracts, it was -- I don't want to get into a lot of the details, it was capitalizing expense items and things of that ilk. We have internal accounting policies on transition costs and things like that where they're capitalization is capped and to capitalize the items, it's very careful consideration kind of things. So it was kind of a broad based misapplication of all the appropriate accounting rules.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: The adjustments were not material to that threshold and we'll elucidate more on it when you read the Q.
componenttext: The adjustments were not material to that threshold and we'll elucidate more on it when you read the Q.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's a systemic reason, if you should read into that. It's just a timing issue.
componenttext: No, there's a systemic reason, if you should read into that. It's just a timing issue.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the questions. And operator, I think we're now ready to wrap up the call and Mike Laphen will close it down for us now.
componenttext: Thanks for the questions. And operator, I think we're now ready to wrap up the call and Mike Laphen will close it down for us now.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, thank you, everyone for joining us today. I hope we provided the clarity for you. We understand it was -- there was some complexity in this quarter's results, but hopefully, we have given the clarity you need to do a proper assessment of our
componenttext: Well, again, thank you, everyone for joining us today. I hope we provided the clarity for you. We understand it was -- there was some complexity in this quarter's results, but hopefully, we have given the clarity you need to do a proper assessment of our performance, which we think was solid and good. As I said earlier, we're pleased with our underlying performance and we look forward to the second half and to a good solid fiscal year. Thank you very much.

headline: Computer Sciences Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, that will conclude today's teleconference. Thank you again for your participation.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, that will conclude today's teleconference. Thank you again for your participation.
